editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Unnatural Mother, THE SCENE in the Kingdom OF SIAM.
As it is now Acted at the New Theatre in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, BY His MAJESTY's Servants.
LONDON, Printed by J. O. for R. Baſſet, at the Mitre in Fleet-ſtreet, near Temple-Bar. 1698.

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.l: WHO is't wou'd be a Poet in our days,
When e'ery Coxcomb crowns his Head with Bays,
And ſtands a ſawcy Candidate for Praiſe?
The Stage is quite debauch'd, for every Day
Some new-born Monſter's ſhown you for a Play;
Art Magick is for Poetry profeſt,
Horſes, Aſſes, Monkeys, and each obſcener Beaſt,
(To which Egyptian Monarch once did bow)
Ʋpon our Engliſh Stage are worſhip'd now.
Fletcher's deſpis'd, your Johnſon's out of faſhion,
And Wit's the only Drug in all the Nation.
Whilst Scenes, Machines, and empty Opera's reign,
And for the Pencil you the Pen diſdain,
Nature is out of count'nance, and gives place
To beaſtly Mimickry and vile Grimace.
A Woman now comes to reform the Stage,
Who once has ſtood the Brunt of this unthinking Age;
Yet ſhou'd her Pen, her Beauty cannot fail;
But, oh! ſhe vows ſhe'l not her Charms unvail,
Nor ſhall you know, harſh Men, at whom you rail.
Then how you cenſure this her Play beware,
Leſt thro' the Poeteſs you wound the Fair:
But —
If you'll go on to dawn good Sence in ſpight,
I'll be reveng'd on you to morrow night:
In this Side-box ſhe'll ſit, I'll make't my Task,
Before you all, to ſtrip her of her Mask;
Oh, how your Malice then you will repent,
And court thoſe Favours which ſhe ſhall not grant!
Her Face once ſeen, ſhe cannot want Applauſe,
For Wit and Beauty both will plead her Cauſe.

div.head: Perſons Repreſented.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Cemat, Son to Callapia by a former Husband.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Bebbemeah, Daughter to Pechai by a former Wife.
Choufera, Daughter to Callapia, and Siſter to Cemat.

div.p: SCENE Levo, a Province in the Kingdom of SIAM.

div.head: ACT I.
Scene Levo, a Province in the Kingdom of Siam.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: HOW can you call me Friend, and thus conceal a Grief from me almoſt diſtracts you? All Night you ſigh'd and wept, and in your broken Slumbers ſtarted, and cry'd, Oh that fatal Grove! Tell me, my Bebbemeah, I conjure thee, by all the Love we ever vow'd each other, make me a Sharer in your killing Sorrows.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O, do not preſs my yielding Heart to tell the only Secret I e'er hid from you; alas, you'l blame my weakneſs, and, inſtead of Pity, meet with your Contempt.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Is't poſſible to think ſo meanly of Choufera? Have we not from our tender Infancy lov'd far beyond the common Ties of Blood, in all our harmleſs Joys been a partaker with each other, and can you think I would contemn you in diſtreſs? Unkind Bebbemeah! I will not call you Friend; if you can meet with one more faithful to you than Choufera has alwaies been, I wiſh it you. (going.)

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay Choufera, would you for one Denial throw me from your Breaſt? O, do not add that weight to what I already feel, I will moſt faithfully diſcharge my Heart of that vaſt load of Grief which almoſt overwhelms me, but you muſt promiſe not to chide me, I cannot bear your Anger.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Pray do not fear it, I'll eaſe you of half the burden, by bearing it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p:
You know by what Engagements I am promiſed by my Father to Munzuffer, to which with blind Obedience I gave confent, having only indifference for all Mankind; but, O my dear Choufera, I am 〈…〉 longer Miſtreſs of my Heart, for yeſterday, a fatal day I fear 〈…〉 , I went to paſs the tedious hours your Abſence made
me think ſo in the Orange grove, where we ſo oft have been, I ſeated my ſelf by the cool purling Stream, a Melancholy ſeized me, I knew not why, as a Forerunner of my Woes to come, a gentle Slumber crept unawares upon me; but long I had not ſlept, when I was wak'd by trampling of a Horſe; I ſtarted up, and the firſt Object preſented to my view was a Youth of Heavenly form, kneeling at my Feet.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Go on, my Deareſt.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible to tell you my Surpriſe, and his appear'd to be no leſs than mine; If you're the Goddeſs of theſe Groves, ſaid he, forgive the raſhneſs of a Stranger, who thus preſumes to worſhip; but if of mortal race, I do conjure you by all the Powers of Love, to tell me who you are. So ſoon as recover'd my Amazement, I told him I was Daughter to Pechai a private Gentleman, who lived far from thence; and, that with my Father I was going hence next day: I ſee he had Servants waiting at a diſtance, but I entreated him ſo earneſtly not to follow me, at laſt he promis'd me upon his Honour he would not; Go, go fair Tyrant, cried he, and boaſt, whoe'er thou art, you've rob'd a hapleſs Youth of his dear Liberty, which all the Beauties of our Eaſt could never do before; but be aſſur'd, where'er thou goeſt, I'll find thee out, tho' in the remoteſt corner of the World.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: And ſo you parted.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Oh, no, I had no power to leave him, with Paſſion he talk'd on, and moving Eloquence enough to warm the Heart of cold Diana; Night drew her ſable Curtains, and forc'd us to a cruel ſeparation, I fear for ever; the Soul parts from the Body not with more reluctancy than we did from each other; nor was I ſo much Miſtreſs of my ſelf, but he, alas, perceived it. I could run on and draw this Story to an endleſs length; at laſt I homeward went by ſeveral turnings, that he might not diſcern which way I took. Forgive, my dear Choufera, my prolixity, and pity my misfortune.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I do with all my Soul; but why did you ſo carefully conceal the Knowledg who you were?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I durſt not truſt ſo powerful a Temptation to draw me from my Duty to my Father.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: He ever promis'd not to force your inclination.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: And I never to diſobey his Will; his Goodneſs to me is the Rock on which I'm loſt, and I reſolve to ſacrifice my Happineſs to his Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: You never yet ſee Munzuffer, and 'tis poſſible might not have lik'd him, if you had not ſeen this Stranger.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: All People ſpeak of him in ſuch high Characters, I fear I ſhall not find out one Excuſe that will ſeem juſt; he's young, has Wit and Senſe, and beautiful to admiration, good-humour'd, brave, and generous, what Objections can there be to theſe Qualities, that will not diſcover the Prepoſſeſſion of my Heart to be the only Cauſe. (ſighs) I muſt obey my Deſtiny, and all I wiſh is, that he may be like my lovely Stranger: Why do I call him mine, (paſſionately) when there is ſcarce a probability I e'er ſhall ſee him more? What have I done, good Heavens, that you ſhould puniſh me with ſuch unlucky Love?

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Compoſe your ſelf, your Father's coming.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Perſwade me not, I'll hear no more; Have I not promis'd her to Sennorat's Son, the noble young Munzuffer?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: You promis'd her before to me, for my Son Cemat, who is as worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: You know ſhe hates him, and I will ne'er compel her to any thing ſhe likes not.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Girls Humours are not to be conſulted, they may like to day what yeſterday they hated, juſt as the Fancy takes 'em; if you thus fondly leave her to her own choice, ſhe may not perhaps like the Match you're ſo deſirous of, but bring a Son of her own ſeeking to call you Father, that you may bluſh to own.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: I know ſo well her Obedience, I fear it not; ſh'as promis'd me to marry Munzuffer, I know ſhe will: What ſay you Bebbemeah, will you not keep your Word with me?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: You may command me, Sir, to any thing, you ne'r ſhall find me wanting in my Duty.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Where was your Duty when he commanded you to receive the Addreſs of my Son? But when a young Girl likes her Man, then, then it is Obedience.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: She knows not yet whether ſhe does or no, ſhe never ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: She hears he's a ſmug young fellow, a pretty Play-thing for a fooliſh Child, had ſhe underſtood Merit, ſhe'd found it in my Son.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Since you will force me then to tell you ſo, tho' I left her to her ſelf in that Affair, I did not think him worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
Nay, now you wrong him, baſely wrong him, by the Gods you do; what if his Body is not ſo well made as that of her young
Paramour, he has a Soul as great as was Alcides: Not worthy of her, that raw, young, fooliſh thing, who underſtands no other Merit in a Man but a fine gay out-ſide! it ſhall be try'd who's the worthieſt man.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: You ne'er were wanting to give her your ill word; come to my Cloſet Bebbemeah, I muſt ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Come hither, my Choufera, can you thus tamely hear thy Brother injur'd, and not thirſt to be reveng'd on that proud Girl?

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: He is not the firſt man has been denied in an amorous Suit; it is impoſſible to force an inclination where 'tis not natural, nor can I think him injur'd by it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
Not injur'd! baſe, baſe degenerate Choufera! Oh! I ſhall burſt with Rage; hence, from my ſight. Exit Chouf.
Something I yet will do to break this Match, 'twas all my Hopes in marrying this old Dotard to get this Fortune for Cemat; thus to have all my Hopes blown into Air, and fruſtrated by a young beardleſs Boy, I am all Fury: Who waits there? bid my Son come to me here, if he has Spirit, as I believe he has, it ſhall be try'd what he durſt do to right himſelf and me. (Pauſes.) It muſt be ſo, I know no other way. Enter Cemat.
Do you not hear, Cemat, that Bebbemeah is ſnatch'd from your Arms, and given to another?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Let her be whoſe ſhe will, I care not, were but her Fortune mine.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: That's right, my Son, but there's no way to compaſs that without the Woman too.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Do but direct me what you'd have me do, I have a Hand and Heart I dare imploy in any gainful miſchief.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: O, thou reviv'ſt my almoſt-dying Hopes, thou wert born to be thy Mother's only Bleſſing: This Munzuffer, this happy Rival comes, he hourly is expected, you want no Friends to ſerve you on ſuch occaſions, way-lay him in the Wood through which you know he paſſes, and ſpoil his fine Addreſſes; you underſtand me, do it, and leave the reſt unto thy Mother's Care.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: What, murder him, you mean; conclude it done, you ne'er ſhall ſee him here.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Succeſs attend, I'll leave thee to contrive it.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (alone) Murder him! what ſhould I get by that? not the Miſtreſs which I love, but one I hate, becauſe ſhe loves not me: Shall I do it for Miſchief's ſake? There's no great danger in't, he knows me not, and I ſhall diſappoint the ſilly Girl; if I can get her Fortune, no matter whether I love her or no, or ſhe me, 'twill purchaſe others, but will it buy thy Siſter, ha Cemat! that, that's the Saint you worſhip: What! love thy own Siſter! why, where's the harm? ſhe's a handſom young ſprightly Wench, and made to be enjoy'd, and why not by her Brother? (Pauſes) Did not Jupiter lye with his Siſter? Ah, but he's a God, they ſay, and may do what he pleaſes, without being accountable to Mortals; oh, for his Showre of Gold, the moſt powerful ſhape he e'er aſſum'd, that I might wanton in my Danae's Arms. Two pretty Undertakings I'm upon, that's the Truth on't, Murder and Inceſt, (Pauſes) Names, Names invented by the crafty Prieſts, to frighten Boys, and keep the Ignorant in ſubjection to them. —

lg.l: I'll murder him, his Miſtreſs to enjoy,
Raviſh my Siſter, if the Fool is coy,
And ſet the World on fire e'er I will loſe one Joy.

div.stage: Juſt as he is going off, enter Callapia.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Stay and take freſh Intelligence, here's a Meſſenger juſt arriv'd from Sennorat.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: From Sennorat, ſay you? conduct him in.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Now, my Choufera, I am loſt indeed; this Meſſage comes to bring the tidings of his approach.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: You know not that, have Patience till you ſee the reſult.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman, who delivers a Letter to Pechai, he reads diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: There's ſome unwelcome News, do you obſerve him?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I do, and hope the Gods, in pity to me, have given ſome interruption to his coming.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: My Service to your Lord, tell him, I will ſuddenly return an Anſwer by a Servant of my own. Exit Gentleman. (Aſide) What can this mean? ſure Sennorat would not fool me in this Concern; he's a Man of that nice Honour, I think he would not do it: Here Bebbemeah, peruſe that Letter, 'tis you are moſt concern'd. Gives her the Letter.

div.stage: [While ſhe reads Cemat looks over her ſhoulder.]

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (to Call. aſide) There's no occaſion for murdering, he's diſpos'd of another way; go to your Chamber, I'll follow, and tell you the Contents.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (to Pech.) I find the Secret's only for your Daughter's Ear, I'll rid you of the Conſtraint my company put on you.

div.stage: gives Cemat her Hand, and exit, Chouf. follows.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Sure Heaven is not propitious to this Match, not one kind Star has ſmil'd upon it yet, I'le think on it more; What ſay you, Bebbemeah, art thou contented to be thus neglected, and loſe a rich young Husband?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: You are to me a Husband, Father, all things; whilſt I enjoy the Bleſſing of your Life, I ne'er ſhall think my ſelf unhappy.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: My Care ſhall always be for your Advantage, I'le go and anſwer Sennorat's Letter. Exit Pechai.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Kind Heaven has heard my Prayers, and I'm releas'd of half my Cares already. Enter Choufera. Come and rejoice with me, my dear Choufera; ſee what a world of Grief theſe Letters have remov'd from Bebbemeah's Heart.

body.p: 'Tis with a Confuſion great as my Affliction that I acquaint you with the diſappointment of my Hopes; my rebellious Son, by whom I was to gain the Honour of your Alliance, has left me without giving further Reaſons for it than what he inſerts in the Note I have enclos'd, ſent you, which was deliver'd to me after his flight: Judge of my Trouble, and conſider his Folly as the raſhneſs of an unadviſed young Man, who will, I hope, quickly ſee his Error, and return to his Duty.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Never, I hope; proceed, my Dear, to the other.

body.p:
I have alwaies been unworthy of the Care you took of my Happineſs, but much more ſince the Affairs of my Heart are changed, which renders me uncapable of the Honour was intended me in the fair Bebbemeah, who has too much Merit only to ſhare a Heart; mine is prepoſſeſs'd by an Accident, as unforeſeen by me as unwelcome to you: I fly your Anger, not being able to obey you,
and I beg you, with as much Compaſſion as your Reſentment will permit, to conſider 'tis a Paſſion not to be reſiſted, tho' I have made my utmoſt Efforts to overcome it, 'tis the only Fault I have committed, who in all other things am your dutiful Son,

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: 'Tis true, you're freed from the Apprehenſions of marrying one you love not, but ſee not how 'twill compaſs him you love; do not you now repent your owning your Name and Quality.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.l: Since Fortune is ſo kind, I'le hope the beſt,
Rejoice at this, and truſt her with the reſt.

div.head: Scene the Second, a Grove.
div.stage: Enter Munzuffer and Rulup, in riding habits.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: I'm almoſt weary with riding theſe few miles; what a vaſt Load's the Body when the Soul's oppreſs'd! At yonder ſtately Pagode there lives a learned Tallapoy, profoundly read in Art and Nature's Secrets, he may inform me what my Stars deſign, and teach my wandring ſteps to find out what I'm in ſearch of; Do you know him, Rulup?

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: Know him, yes Sir, I have heard enough of him to tremble at his very Name; why, he's the Devil incarnate, would you go to the Devil, Sir, for a Woman?

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Away, you Fool! he is a mighty Prophet, Auſtere of Life, a Favourite of the holy Gods, can their Decrees foretell, and what is writ in the dark Book of Fate; go tell him I beg to ſpeak with him, and wait his coming here.

div.stage: Rulup going out, runs back again.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: O S • r! no ſooner conjure, but you know who's in the Circle. Yonder he comes, I beſeech you let me go, I'm not holy enough for his company; beſides, Sir, you may have Secrets to diſcourſe on are not fit a poor Serving-man ſhould hear. going.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Stay ſirrah, I charge you, I may perhaps have uſe of you.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: Uſe! I'm not fit for the uſe of any living Creature at this time, but if I muſt ſtay, I'll ſecure my ſelf as well as I can; I believe, for all his holineſs, he ſeldom looks up to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Hail reverend Father, pitiful and good, vouchſafe to tell the Deſtiny of him whom Love has made unhappy.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: I will, I'm therefore hither ſent by the great Gods, to whom thy Virtues are moſt dear; deſcend thou airy Spirit, thou that of Lovers tak'ſt the greateſt care, and tell this Love-ſick Youth the utmoſt he would know. To Munz. Attend moſt heedfully to what ſhe utters, thy Happineſs or Miſery depends upon it.

lg.l: YOƲ fly from what you ſeek, deny what you implore;
Return, thy Father's Grief to cheer,
Tell him thy Love, and do not fear,
'Tis he thy Doubts can clear,
And to thy longing Wiſh thy Miſtreſs will reſtore.
The helliſh fatal Siſters thy ſenſes will beguile,
Thy envy'd Joys they will debar,
And cauſe a deadly mortal Jar,
Of Jealouſie beware,
Thy Sight too will delude thee, and Innocence exile.
The Parricide, who woo's thee to her lewd Bed, deteſt;
For Heaven will at laſt agree
To crown thy conſtant Loyalty,
And happy thou ſhalt be;
Take warning, gentle Youth, and be for ever bleſt.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Thanks, holy Father, for this kind Admonition.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Be careful, noble Munzuffer, there is a dreadful Fate hangs o'er your Head, be virtuous, and be happy. Exit Tallapoy.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Some Power above direct me what to do, and ſteer my Actions to your Heavenly Will. Come down, you Coward, do you not ſee he's gone? to Rul.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p:
No indeed, not I, my Eyes have been cloſe ſhut, and my Ears ſtop'd, I would not countenance their diabolical Muſick by my attention; beſides, I have heard of ſome fine ſinging things that draw
their liſt'ners to follow them whether they will or no, perhaps ſhe might be one of them.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Syrens you mean.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: I know not what you call them, but I heard a Story of a great Man that tied himſelf to the Maſt, for fear of leaping into the Sea after them.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: A very famous Story indeed, Ʋlyſſes, was it not?

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: I think he had ſome ſuch cramp Name; but be it what it will, his Example, for ought I know, has ſaved me from breaking my neck.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Come down you Sot.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: As ſoon as I can get looſe.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Go, bring the Horſes, I'll go back again, what think you of that?

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: (coming down) Think of it, why, I ſhall love the Devil the better for't as long as I live, if 'twas he adviſed you to it; I was ne'er cut out for a Squire, I hate this Knight-erranting, I'd rather be your Worſhip's Groom ſtill with three good Meals a day, than a lank Squire, to feed on Air and Lovers Tears.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Hold your prophane Tongue Sirrah, and do as I command.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: (pulls out a Picture) Oh, lovely ſhadow of my ador'd Saint! what Charms are here in theſe bewitching Eyes! ſmile, ſmile my Fortune, and give this wondrous Beauty to my longing Arms, I ask no other Boon, were ſhe but mine, I would not change her for all the Treaſure of our Eaſtern Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Rul.
sp.p: (aſide) So, he's at his Devotion I ſee by the Book. Sir, the Horſes are ready at the end of the Grove.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.l: T' appeaſe my angry Father I will go,
Who if my Miſtreſs finds, will more beſtow
Than all his Wealth can give me here below. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the First ACT.

div.head: ACT II.
Scene a Wood.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: NAY, further yet; it is a Secret of that great importance, the remoteſt corner of this mighty Wood is hardly private enough.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I'm ſure we have no overhearers in this place, and I'm ſo weary I can go no further.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (aſide) So I would have her, ſhe may be too ſtrong for me elſe. And do you think this place is very private? to her.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: You ſee it is an unfrequented Path by the high Graſs, I do believe no human Ear can reach us.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Then this it is: Siſter, I love you, nay, ſtart not, more than a Brother ſhould, and muſt enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Good Heavens! what mean you Brother, you are not ſure in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Why not in earneſt? Is it ſuch a Wonder to love a pretty Woman?

sp.speaker: Chouf
sp.p: I'm ſure you jeſt, and tell me ſo to fright me.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: If any Crime there be, 'tis you're the cauſe; your Honour is ſecure with me: Come, come, my dear Choufera, let's be free, I'll give you a ſtrong Proof how much I love you. takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Stand off, foul Monſter; what villainous intentions thou art bent upon, prophane thy own Blood, raviſh thy Siſter! Think, think Cemat, upon the horrid Deed.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I did not bring you here to rail, and am reſolv'd, if you will not conſent, to force you.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I'll rend the Skies with ſhrieks, and move ſome pitying God, a Friend to Chaſtity, to come to my aſſiſtance; and ſee, my Prayers are heard. He turns haſtily to look behind, the while ſhe runs off.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Ha! is ſhe gone? ſhe ſhall not eſcape me ſo, I ſoon ſhall overtake her. Runs off.
sp.stage: Enter Sennorat and Munzuffer, Sennorat ſpeaks as he enters.
sp.p:
Let the Coach go ſoftly up the Hill, 'tis a cool pleaſant Morning, we'l walk and overtake it: Diſperſe that Cloud upon thy Brow Munzuffer, and look as if thou wert to ſee thy fair loſt Miſtreſs: Have
not I promis'd I will put no Force upon thy Heart? ſhe may be like the Picture which you ſhew'd me, and therefore you may love her.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I wiſh I may, Sir, to oblige the kindeſt Father ever Son was bleſs'd with.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (within) Help, help; is no one near?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Ha! a Womans Voice, it ſounded this way; Art t' gone? The Youth is too nimble for me. Draws, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: But I'll not ſtay behind. Exit after him.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Whoe'er they be, curſe on 'em, for coming juſt the very minute, a little longer, and I had enjoy'd my Ends, and then ſhe would have kept the Secret for her own ſake. But this is no place to ſtay in, I'll get home before her, and if the ſilly Slut does tell her Tale, why I'll forſwear it. Exit Cemat.

div.stage: Enter Sennorat and Munzuffer, leading Choufera.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I'm ſorry the Villain 'ſcap'd us.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Baniſh your fears, Madam, you are ſecure, we'l ſee you ſafely home, where e'er it be.

sp.speaker: Clouf.
sp.p: How ſhall I return my Thanks to Heaven and you for this deliverance? (Aſide) Sure ſome malevolent Star reign'd at my Birth; what I have gain'd by this moſt timely ſuccour, I've loſt another way:
sp.l: Oh Bebbemeah! a Fate like thine I mourn,
A Stranger love, and for one I know not, burn.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Compoſe your Thoughts, fair Lady, and tell us where 'tis we ſhall wait on you.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Since to the mighty Obligation I ſtand indebted for, you yet will add a freſh one, which I dare not refuſe, for fear again of that bold Raviſher from whom you reſcued me; on yonder Hill, at that great Houſe, is where I live.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: At Pechai's! 'tis thither we are going.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Sure this is not Bebbemeah.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I beg you'd leave me in the Orange-grove, at the entrance to the Park, and to conceal the meeting me in this unlucky place, I have ſome Reaſons for it are fit you ſhould not know at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Fear it not Lady, we'l do as you deſire.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (aſide) Who can theſe be; but 'tis moſt lucky, I ſhall know at leaſt who 'tis has conquer'd me.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Conduct the Lady to the Coach, Munzuffer.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (aſide) Ha! Munzuffer! this is Bebbemeah's fugitive Lover return'd; oh, if ſhe ſee him with my Eyes, what will become of poor unhappy Choufera? Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Scene the Second, Pechai's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Pechai, Callapia, Bebbemeah, a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Munzuffer return'd to his Father, ſay you! art t' ſure on't?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I ſee him; I had juſt deliver'd your Letter to Sennorat, who ſigh'd and almoſt wept, and cried, Ungracious Boy! thou haſt broke thy Father's Heart; but ſtrait a general Joy ran through the Houſe, and nothing but Murzuffer's Name repeated: He ask'd in haſte, diſtruſtful of his Joy, what meant thoſe Acclamations; before he could be anſwer'd, his Son was at his Feet, imploring his Forgiveneſs, which he ſoon obtain'd: He bid me ſay, he'd ſend Munzuffer to beg your Mediation to his injur'd Miſtreſs, and come himſelf to obtain from fair Bebbemeah a Pardon for his Son: I juſt arrived with theſe happy tidings, they will not be long after me. This Letter, Sir, he charged me with to you, and this to fair Bebbemeah.

div.stage: Pechai reads the Letter with ſigns of Joy, Bebbemeah puts hers in her Pocket unopened.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Now, my Bebbemeah, prepare to receive the noble young Munzuffer.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (kneels) Thus low I kneel for Pardon, if I offend in what I have to ſay; I beg you would not give me to this man, who has ſhew'd ſuch ſcorn, and has ſo much deſpiſed me.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I cannot now but join with her, I think her Requeſt is juſt.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Madam▪ I know from whence your Advice proceeds. Riſe my Child, remember what I alway promis'd you, be ſatisfied till you ſee him.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O, where is my Choufera, that I may eaſe my overcharg'd Heart into her friendly Boſom. Exit Bebb.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, Sennorat is arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Conduct him in; Callapia, pray withdraw for a few minutes.

div.stage: Enter Sennorat and Munzuffer, Pechai meets 'em.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Welcome, moſt noble Sennorat, and you, brave Youth.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I'm come, my Lord, with my offending Son, to entreat a Pardon for him.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: (ſmiling) He'l find, I hope, he has no need of any, if what you writ be ſo.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Moſt certainly; know you this Picture? Shews a Picture.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: I do: Who waits there? Enter a Gentleman. Deſire my Wife to bring her Daughters in.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Who can expreſs the Torment I am in! the Wretch who lies extended on a rack is more at eaſe than I am.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Ha! what do I ſee! by all the Powers of Love, the very very ſame; how ſhall I hide my Tranſports?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (aſide to Chouf.) 'Tis he, my dear Choufera, the lovely charming Stranger I ſee in the Orange grove; I am all Joys, O help me to conceal 'em.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (aſide) And I am all Deſpair, unlucky miſerable Choufera!

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: (gives him Beb.) Here Munzuffer, take her to your Wiſhes, I'm not ſo much a ſtranger to both your Hearts, to doubt the Preſent is not acceptable.
To Senn. We will withdraw, my Lord, if you think fit to ſpare a Maidens Bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Lovers Diſcourſes are not for others Ears.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: They ſeem acquainted already, ſure they before have ſeen each other; O, he's a lovely ſweet young Gentleman. Exit Senn. leading Call. Pech. follows; juſt as ſhe is going off, ſhe turns, O, I could gaze on him for ever.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Now, now my Joys are full, divineſt Bebbemeah; but what a world of Grief you would have ſpar'd me, had you not us'd another's Name!

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I'd Reaſons for't, my Lord, which, when convenient, you ſhall know.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Fly, fly you tardy hours, to bring about the time that bleſt Munzuffer may call the matchleſs Bebbemeah his.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: My Lord, I have a doubt I do believe you can reſolve; how came my Lord Sennorat and my Father to know our meeting in the Grove?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: It was the happieſt minute of my Life, I told him of it; when moſt unkindly you had left me alone to my Deſpair, I homeward went full of the Idea of your charming ſelf; next Morning 'twas deſign'd by my Father, for all things were in a readineſs to wait on Bebbemeah, I found out many Excuſes to put it off a little longer, but none were of force enough to prevail: I roſe e're break of Day, and only with one of my Grooms, a ſimple honeſt fellow, I left my Father's Houſe, never to ſee it more till I had at leaſt found out who 'twas had robbed me of my Liberty: By what ſtrange means I was ſent back to my Father, I'll take another time to tell: But after I had gain'd his Pardon for my Diſobedience, I told him my Adventure in the Grove, and ſhew'd him this Picture, which there you drop'd.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I never knew till now which way I loſt it, nor can well remember for what reaſon I ſhould have it about me.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: He ſeem'd o'erjoy'd, embrac'd, and ſaid I ſhould but only ſee, and if your Beauty could not efface that of my Fair unknown, he would not preſs me to it, and help himſelf to find my Charmer out. He ask'd me ſeveral Queſtions, and if I thought my Love was not diſpleaſing to her; Pardon me, lovely Miſtreſs, for I told him, by what I could perceive in the ſmall Converſation we had together, I'd made ſome ſmall impreſſion on your Heart.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: That was the Purport of the Letter, I ſuppoſe, my Father was ſo pleas'd at. I find they deſign to ſurprize us both.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (aſide) What will become of me? I find I'm loſt to all hopes for ever; ah, happy, happy Siſter!

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: My deareſt Bebbem. will you not give me leave to call you ſo, and hope a little Inclination, as well as Duty, gives you to Munzuffer.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: 'Tis time enough, my Lord, for ſuch Confeſſions.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (aſide to Beb.) I can ſtay no longer from this charming Stranger; Bebbemeah, you'l ſurfeit your new Lover with too much forwardneſs; retire, I'll keep him company.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (aſide) Malicious Woman! come Choufera, we muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Curſe on her, what can ſhe mean by this?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
This is a Freedom, Sir, not uſual in our Country, to give young People leave to talk together before they're married; it is her Father's blind Indulgence to her, who ſuffers her in every thing to
follow her own Humour, which alwaies led her to love Mens company; ſhe's of an amorous Complexion.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: That is a rigorous and cruel Cuſtom, all People ought to pleaſe themſelves in ſuch a great concern as Marriage is.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: And do you like her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I love her more than Life, or all things elſe on Earth.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't, ſo pretty a Gentleman deſerves a better Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I want nothing, Madam, in having her, but Merit to deſerve her; ſhe's beautiful to adoration, and virtuous, what can the bleſt Munzuffer wiſh for more?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: The Levity you ſee her guilty of is no great ſign of that.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: It was not only by her Father's Permiſſion, but Command, ſhe gave me leave to tell her that I lov'd her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: You have ſeen her, Sir, before, where you had opportunity enough to tell her often ſo.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: We then were Strangers to each other, and 'twas by accident we met in the Orange-grove.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: A likely matter to meet in ſuch a place by accident.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I'd loſt my Company a hunting, and went to repoſe my ſelf under the cool ſhade, not knowing ſhe was there, nor any elſe; 'tis very eaſie to give credit to me, if you conſider why I refuſed to marry Bebbemeah, whilſt I went in ſearch of her, far from knowing I fled from the Happineſs I was ſeeking.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (aſide) So, this is the Secret was kept ſo cloſe from me; I do not think, Sir, the Rendezvouze was given to you, but ſome one elſe, of which your coming diſappointed her.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: That I cannot believe, I'm ſati • fied ſhe loves me, and no one elſe; I ſaw it by an hundred Signs at the very time I mention.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (aſide) This will not do, I find, I muſt be plain, I have no time to loſe, for all things are with haſte a preparing for the Wedding-day; I'll tell him that I love him, and if he dares refuſe me, his Scorn ſhall ſeal his Doom. To him. Suppoſe, my Lord, there was another lov'd you, tho' not ſo young, perhaps more faithful far, would you for this fond fooliſh Girl refuſe her?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: There is no danger, Madam, of that tryal of my Faith, it needs no ſerious Anſwer. Going.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Oh ſtay, too lovely Stranger, and take the ſoft Confeſſion of my Soul; 'tis I my ſelf that love thee, charming Youth, and here I ſwear to die, if you refuſe me yours.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Direct me, Heaven, that gave me Warning of it, which way to ſhun this Womans wicked Love; ſhould I poſitively deny, I fear ſhe'l take ſome fatal courſe to rob me of my Miſtreſs; I'le flatter her Hopes till I'm poſſeſs'd of my dear Bebbemeah, and then I fear her not.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Why do you pauſe, Sir? Is it ſo hard a thing to love again where you are beſt belov'd?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, if I am ſurpriz'd; I am not worthy of the leaſt part of your Affection, you have a noble Husband, who beſt deſerves it all, I would not rob him of his juſt ſhare to be the happy man my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Suppoſe I were a Widow, would you then love me and quit my hated Rival?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Gods! what ſhall I ſay? Direct my erring Tongue. You are more charming and deſerving than I can expreſs, but whilſt you are another's Right, I muſt not love you: I muſt beg leave to retire, I am not well. Exit Munz.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: If that be all, the Objection I will ſoon remove, this feeble doating Husband ſhall not live to bar me of my Bliſs, and I doubt not but the Wealth I have unknown, and what I add by Bebbemeah's Ruin, which I will contrive to make her Fortune mine, will charm his wavering Heart. Enter Cemat. Welcome Cemat, thou'rt come the very minute I was wiſhing for thee.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (aſide) So, I find all ſafe enough yet. What, to diſpatch my gay young Rival, is it not? To her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I charge thee touch him not; no, no Cemat, I have another Game to play, in which you muſt aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (aſide) Plague on this Diſappointment, that it ſhould be my Rival too; I muſt keep out of ſight, if they ſee me, all my Deſigns on my Siſter may be prevented.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Thou mind'ſt me not, what ailst' Cemat?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I do, Madam, moſt heedfully; pray go on, and tell me what it is you'd have me do.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: A matter which you with greateſt eaſe may compaſs, a Doſe of Poiſon for my Husband. Cemat ſtarts. What doſt thou ſtart at? dar'ſt thou not undertake what I dare project? Do you but procure it, the reſt I'll ſee perform'd.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I'm only vex'd to be outdone in Wickedneſs; you have it, 〈◊〉 me but the reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: It is for thy advantage and my happineſs this wiſe Munzuffer, this wondrous Young-man, love mes Cemat, and would marry me, were Pechai but remov'd out of the way, and then, without controul, thou maiſt have Bebbemeah.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (pulls out of Vial and gives her) I have alwaies ſuch a neceſſary thing at hand, take this, and in his Coffee give him juſt ten drops, I dare engage my Life 'twill do his buſineſs, the Operation will be very ſpeedy.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo, or I ſhall have Munzuffer ſnatch'd from me; I'le loſe no time, but inſtantly about it. Exit Call.

This honeſt old virtuous Fool I've alwaies been in fear of, I'm glad he's ſo diſpoſed; like the fierce Ranger of the Libian Deſarts, I now will reign without controul in my Pleaſures; I am my Mothers Son I dare to ſwear, but ſure Choufera's no Child of hers, Virtue, Modeſty, and Goodneſs, thank Pluto, were never Attributes of our Family: I muſt take new meaſures with this skittiſh Girl, pretend Penitence, and beg her Pardon, I ſhall never elſe get another opportunity, ſhe ſo carefully aviods me; I ſee her coming, I'le abſcond till I have ſecur'd her to hear me ſpeak. He abſconds.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Where ſhall I go to give my Sorrows vent, and eaſe my poor ſunk Heart, oppreſt with Grief and Sadneſs? I have no Friend to pour out my Complaints to: O happy Bebbemeah, happy lucky Siſter! I'le not diſturb thy Joys with the unfortunate Story of my Woes, I know ſo well thou lov'ſt Choufera, thou'd pity her more than a Rival ought.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (aſide) This is a Secret may be of uſe to me; Hark! ſhe goes on.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Take back, good Gods, the hated Life you lent, let me not live to a long Age of endleſs Miſery: What a falſe Notion is it, that no one loves, but hopes! alas, I have not one to ſave me, falling into the deep Abyſs of horrid dark Deſpair: Unhappy Maid! thou canſt have no Relief from any thing but Death.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (ſhews himſelf) Why talks Choufera of Death? Tell me, my deareſt Siſter, who has wrong'd thee, thy Brother wears a Sword will right thy Injuries.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p:
(aſide) I hope he has not o'erheard me.
To him 'Tis thou thy ſelf, moſt wicked man, be gone, or I will publiſh thy impious Crime, and make thee abhorr'd as much as thou deſerv'ſt.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I have a Secret, Madam, of yours in keeping, you would not be well pleas'd I ſhould diſcover: you love Munzuffer, Choufera; nay, bluſh not, 'tis no Crime.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Still, ſtill unlucky in all I ſay or do?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Choufera, ſay not that you have no Friend, you ſhall always find a true one of your Brother; diſtruſt me not, I would redeem the Injuries I intended thee with the laſt drop of all my Blood; I come to ask your Pardon for my raſh Attempt, which thus I humbly beg, (kneels) believe theſe Tears, (weeps) my Soul's all Penitence, and take me to your Mercy.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Riſe Cemat, I do forgive you, ask it of Heaven, 'twas a moſt foul Attempt, and not a common Sin.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (weeping) I do moſt earneſtly, and beg you will not name it any more, I'm all Confuſion at the thoughts of it, tho' Heaven and you're ſo good to pardon me, I never ſhall forgive my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: O Cemat, thou know'ſt the only Secret of my Life, keep it I charge thee, as you would one that would betray thy Liberty or Life.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: My Life is but a Trifle, I would give that to expiate my Offence; rely on me, and if I can without a Crime make Munzuffer yours, it ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: O no, I would not injure Bebbemeah's Happineſs to gain my own; ſhe lov'd him with a boundleſs Paſſion before I ſaw him, he is her Due▪ my Fate's unalterable, I wiſh for nothing but a Grave to hide my Sorrows in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (laughs) Ha, ha, ha, poor eaſie Fool, to believe he who dar'd to offer ſuch a Violence can ſo ſoon repent; I'll flatter her in her love for Munzuffer, that will be one way to get my ſelf into her good Opinion, which I muſt be poſſeſs'd of to get her in my power.

div.stage: Scene draws, diſcovers Pechai in torment, as poyſon'd; Sennorat, Munzuffer, Bebbemeah

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p:
Throw me in Ice, and cover me with Snow, to cool this raging Fever in my Bowels, I'm all in flames, I burn, I burn; convey
me to the River Menam, where I may quench my moſt immoderate thirſt.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Run for Phyſicians, let no Art be ſpar'd to ſave my deareſt Husband's precious Life: O moſt unfortunate Callapia! I'll not outlive my deareſt Lord, but periſh with his Aſhes.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: A Chill now runs through all my Veins, Agues and Fevers ſucceſſively by turns torture my periſhing Entrails, O lay me, lay me in the hot Beams of the moſt ſcorching Sun, or plunge me in the Streams of boyling Phlegeton. I'm now again on fire; Sennorat, Munzuffer, Wife, Daughter, all, all help to quench me. I feel a Numbneſs ſeize on all my Limbs, and Death ſteal gently on me; I am now at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O moſt unhappy day of all my Life! my deareſt tendereſt Father, give me your Bleſſing e're your Soul departs.

sp.speaker: Pech.
sp.p: Thou haſt it, Child: My Lord Sennorat, take her to your Care, and when my Funeral Obſequies are over, give her to Munzuffer; farewel, a long farewel to all. Dies.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: O ſtay and take me with you: He's gone, he's gone, and I will follow him. Swoons.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Look to the Lady there, bow her, and give her Air; dry up thy Tears, Bebbemeah, I'll be a Father to thee; we muſt ſubmit to the Decrees of Fate, do not afflict thy ſelf for what thy Tears can never bring thee back.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (comes to her ſelf) What have you done with him? Oh, let me bath his cold dead Cheeks in the warm Torrent of my boundleſs Tears. Swoons again.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Carry her to her Apartment — True Grief is ſeldom thus outragious: Come Bebbemeah, thou art my Charge.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Such Grief as mine, admits no lookers on; pray, Sir, give me leave to retire to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I muſt not leave you to ſuch Grief, fair Mourner, I'll wait on you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene ſhuts on the Body, Cemat comes forward.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: So, he's ſafe enough; O excellent Woman! fit only to be the Mother of Cemat!

div.stage: As he goes off, enter Callapia, and calls him.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Hiſt, Cemat, come back, Pechai's dead, do'ſt know it?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I do, I ſtood conceal'd and ſee your Grief, I almoſt thought it real, you counterfeited rarely.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Now Cemat, I will pretend ſuch an unbounded Grief, that like our Indian Wives, who burn themſelves in the Pile which conſumes their Husbands Bodies, ſo I will feign to do, 'twill take off ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: You may ſafely venture to attempt it, you know 'tis not the Cuſtom of our happier Siameſes, and 'twill not be permitted you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: But you however ſhall to Choufera, and tell her my intention, and beg her to be earneſt with Sennorat to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: You need not doubt, Choufera will be ſure to do her part, her love to you will prompt her quickly to undertake it as ſoon as I have told her; I'll inſtantly about it. Exit Cem.

With Caution I muſt act, I have a mighty Game to play before Munzuffer will be mine; if Bebbemeah dies, her Fortune comes to me by Contract of my Marriage with Pechai; but let her live for my Cemat, I have enough, I hope, to dazle the young Eyes of my dear lovely Charmer, and move his Father to conſider my Fortune, in value far exceeding hers, to be the better Match for his brave Son: I had a Prince, when I was young, who was my private Lover, from whoſe vaſt Bounty I rais'd a moſt invaluable Treaſure, which I moſt carefully conceal'd from Pechai's Knowledge, and likewiſe my firſt Husband, in whoſe days it was; this I will ſhew to Sennorat, and his moſt charming Son: But ſomething I muſt do with Bebbemeah, to ruine her in the good Opinion of both the Son and the Father, but I will try all Arts to win him firſt by fair and gentle means: They're both coming this way, now for my Handkercher and Tears again.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I had juſt ſent for you, my Lord, to let you know my Reſolution's fix'd to expire in the Pile whoſe flames are to conſume the dear dead Body of my much-lov'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I cannot but commend the Piety to your departed Husband, but 'tis not a Cuſtom here that will be countenanc'd, therefore you muſt forbear the Thoughts, and live to be a Comfort to your Children.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
Alas! what's Life to me now he is gone, the only Comfort of it? I have that to leave my Son and Daughter, beſide the Proviſion
already made moſt largely, will provide for them, and make 'em always happy, which I'll ent •• ſt you with, to ſee it equally diſpos'd to both: Draw in that Cheſt. calls at the Door.

div.stage: Servant draws in a Cheſt, and exit; ſhe opens the Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Prodigious! this is a maſs would enrich an Emperor! whence came this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: 'Twas given to my Father by our late King of Siam, for a private Service he did him, who left it all to me.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: If you reſolve to die, I will with Juſtice ſee your Will perform'd; Choufera I will take into my Care, your Son's a Man, I hear, and will not like a Guardian.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I beg, my Lord, you'd ſee the Rites prepar'd, I have a greater buſineſs takes up all my Thoughts. Exit Call.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I come, my Lord, with my afflicted Siſter, to beg you'd ſave her Mother from the hard Death we hear ſhe'as doom'd her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I do deſign, fair Ladies, to prevent it, but ſhe's ſo bent upon it, I fear there's no prevailing with her to lay the Thoughts aſide; let her, to ſatisfie her Melancholy Humour, appear in all the ſolemn Pomp us'd on ſuch occaſions, and in the ſight of all the lookers on I'll interpoſe and ſave her.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: May you be ever bleſt in all you wiſh, for this kind Pity. Aſide Would I might die for her, and looſe this miſerable Load of Life I bear. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: This I have overheard moſt luckily; thus far Succeſs has crown'd my Deſigns.

lg.l: The Brave that dare may always happy be,
Laugh at the Fates, and baffle Deſtiny.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Scene draws, diſcovers the Body of Pechai laid on a Pile of Wood, Callapia dreſs'd in white, ſeated at the feet of Pechai's Body, with a Garland of Flowers on her Head; Sennorat, Munzuffer, Cemat at a diſtance, Bebbemeah and Choufera in mourning Veils, ſix Prieſts, and two Women. Two Prieſts and two Women ſing the following

div.head: Song.

sp.speaker: Firſt Prieſt.
sp.l: HEnce, you infernal Spirits, come not near
This ſacred Pile, let thoſe pure Aſhes reſt:
His ſpotleſs Soul to the great God's most dear
Aſcend through theſe bright Flames up to the Bleſt.

sp.speaker: Second Prieſt.
sp.l: O Veſpa! place this Ʋrn ſafe from the reach
Of the black Serpent of the Houſe of Smoak:
Let his moſt pious Life Example teach,
The God of thouſand Gods we thus invoke.
Great Tanagoopoo, hear our Prayer,
Theſe Aſhes take into thy Care;
Keep the foul Dragon in his Den,
The Enemy of Gods and Men.

sp.speaker: Firſt Woman.
sp.l: Thou that to Virgin-Prayers an Ear dost lend,
Sacred Amida, Goddeſs of our Vow,
To thy chaſte Care theſe Aſhes we commend,
Thy Favour to our juſt Requeſt allow.

sp.speaker: Second Woman.
sp.l: To Paradiſe his holy Soul convey,
What happy Spirits on the Good do wait,
Where the bright Sun makes an eternal Day,
Bleſſed for ever from the reach of Fate.

div.stage: They all walk round the Pile, ſinging this Chorus together, and ſet fire to the pile with Torches, which they have in their Hands all the time.

sp.l: Aſcend, ye Flames, up to the Skies,
We with it ſend our Prayers and Cries:
Great Tanagoopoo bow thine Ear,
Vouchſafe our Pray'rs and Tears to hear.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: O ſave her, ſave her from the raging Flames.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: (takes Call. up by the Hand) It is enough, Callapia, you have ſhow'd your Kindneſs to your Husband ſurpaſſing far the common Love of Wives, I muſt not let you die.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Will you not let me go to Paradiſe, moſt barbarous Man!

div.stage: She endeavours to break from him, they all gather about her, and hold her, the Scene ſhuts behind them on the Pile.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Conduct her to her Chamber, and there let's labour all to give her quiet. Exeunt all but Cemat, who comes forward.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you need not take ſuch care of her, ſhe has outdone the very Original of Diſſimulation, I could e'en hug my ſelf to ſee our thriving Plots go on ſo faſt: Are they coming? They muſt not ſee me. Abſconds.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: She's ſo immoderate in her Grief, all Reaſoning is in vain.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: A little time will wear it off, now, Sir, I beg you to proceed to ſolemnize our Marriage, I have ſome boding Thoughts I cannot overcome, which makes me fear my Bebbemeah will be ſnatch'd away.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: That cannot be, my Son, you know ſhe's at my diſpoſal, but to diſperſe thy Fears, this very night ſhe ſhall be yours, beyond the reach of Fortune to take her from you.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (aſide) Say you ſo, you may be miſtaken; this muſt to my Mother. Exit Cemat.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Shine, ſhine my Stars, and Hymen light his Torch, and thou great Goddeſs that attends on Marriage Rites, bleſs our mutual loves. Enter Bebbemeah and Choufera. O Bebbemeah! lovely Miſtreſs, ſay, wilt thou not give thy wondrous Beauty up to bleſt Munzuffer's Longings? This very night gives Bebbemeah to me, and nothing waits to crown my Joys but thy Conſent.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: It is too ſoon, my Lord, to talk of Joys, my deareſt Father's Aſhes yet are warm; delay it longer, 'tis indeed too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: You know it was your Father's dying word, and tho' I may command you to it, I only will entreat; there's danger in Delays, Munzuffer, do not leave her till you have gain'd the point, whilſt I take care that nothing elſe be wanting to compleat it. Exit Senn.

div.stage: Enter haſtily Callapia, Cemat looks in with her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
(to Cem.) To night! it cannot, muſt not be, ſtay you within my Call.
To Beb. Ungrateful Bebbemeah! can you ſo ſoon forget your tender loving Father, to talk of Marriage? the Funeral Pile is hardly yet extinguiſht; withdraw, I'le talk to your Lover about it.

Now all my Fears return. To Munz. Have you forgot, noble Munzuffer, when you the proffer of my Love refus'd, it was becauſe I was another's Right? what hinders now to take me to your Arms inſtead of Bebbemeah? that vaſt Wealth I ſhew'd you ſhall be yours, take it all and me unto your Boſom.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: 'Tis you forget the Grief ſo lately ſhow'd for your dear Husband's death, and, I muſt tell you, 'tis Bebbemeah wholly has my Heart, her Image there ſo deeply is impreſt, nothing can blot it out, do not for pity interrupt my Joys, could I love another, it ſhould be you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: What are thy Joys to me, if I muſt be unhappy? Conſider, Munzuffer, what thou doſt refuſe; I ſue thee for thy Love, ſhe but obeys her Father; beſides, ſhe long ſince was contracted to my Son, her broken Vows will pull down Vengeance from the Gods upon her ſelf and you.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Forbid it Heaven, I love her with that Paſſion, I'll through all Obſtacles whate'er they be, without her I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: And with her too, fond Youth, ſhe's not the virtuous modeſt thing you take her for, ſhe's lewd as Hell, there's ſcarce a Slave or Groom in all her Father's Houſe but has enjoy'd her; you'l find it ſo when 'tis too late to help it.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: It cannot be, I'm ſure you wrong her Virtue; I ſee thou'rt a Counterfeit all over, thy Griefs juſt now were not to be repair'd, and now thou'rt ſuing for another Husband, would you had died before you troubled thus the Quiet of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I would I had indeed, ſince you can be ſo cruel to her who tells you of the danger that you may eſcape; 'twas only for your ſake that I did live, O throw this Proſtitute from thy generous Heart, and take me in her room. Takes his Hand.

sp.speaker: Munz.
Call.
sp.p: (aſide) Patience, I muſt be calm. (To him) Moſt barbarous Munzuffer! is this the Recompence you give my Love? I'le take my ſelf for ever from your ſight, and weep, like Niobe, into a Marble Statue, to leave a laſting Monument of thy unmanly Cruelty. going.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.l: Leave me not, I charge you, come back and tell me.
Yet what I know not. Takes hold of her, ſtamps and turns from her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: You'd have me unſay what I told you of Bebbemeah; is it not ſo, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: (kneels) Was it then falſe? I know it was; ſay but ſo Callapia, ſee, at your Feet Munzuffer falls, unask'd I do forgive you, eaſe but my tortur'd Mind, and ſay ſhe's innocent.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I'le ſay ſo if you pleaſe, or any thing you'd have me.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (riſes) Thou haſt reſtor'd me to my ſelf again; O my divineſt Bebbemeah, pardon my jealous Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: How ſoon you'd cheat your ſelf in what you wiſh! conſider what I ſaid, and think if it be a juſt occaſion of this mighty Joy.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Ha, what ſay you? Did you not tell me ſhe is innocent of thoſe black Crimes you charg'd her with in Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I told you I would ſay what you would have me, did that include her guiltleſs? Worthy Munzuffer, believe e're 'tis too late her Shame and thine, if you joyn Wedlock with this infamous Creature.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: To what a Labyrinth am I hurried on! I'll hear no more, I'm ſure you wrong her, yet I am all diſtraction. Exit Munz.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Go Fool, I think I have ſtung thee to ſome purpoſe, I have not done with thee: Done, did I ſay? I yet have ſcarce begun: if all the Stratagems and Art that Woman ever practis'd can compaſs him, I yet will make him mine. Come in, Cemat, Calls at the Door. Enter Cemat. and help me to effect this Bebbemeah's, this Idol of his Soul's deſtruction, he has downright refus'd my Love.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: What, break his Promiſe to you! his Life ſhall make you ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: No, my Cemat, then I loſe all my Hopes; I've rais'd his thoughts to doubts of her already, which I'le convince him of to be all Truth, by having a black Slave found with her on the Bed, himſelf ſhall ſee it, 'twill ruine her for ever in his Opinion, and cauſe a Breath, which never ſhall be heal'd, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Cem
sp.p: It looks with a good Face, if you can bring it well about.

sp.speaker: Call
sp.p:
(gives him a little Box) Take this Pill, in ſome Liquor diſſolve
it, and give it to one of her own Slaves, no matter which, 'twill cauſe immediate Sleep as ſound as Death, I'le take the ſame care of Bebbemeah, when you have done convey him to her Apartment, and leave me to the reſt.

lg.l: Your Duty in your quick diſpatch be known;
This hour, kind Fate, and then he's ſure my own. Exeunt ſeverally

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: It is a Calumny thrown on her, believe it not, my Son, upon my life you'l find it ſo; however we'l delay the Marriage for ſome time, and keep the ſtricteſt watch on all her Actions; Callapia may have ſome Deſign in it, tho' what I know not.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: (aſide) Too well I gueſs: I know not what to think, but I am more diſtracted with my Doubts than if I knew the worſt, for then I ſhould ſo much abhor her. I ſoon ſhould gain my Quiet.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I never lik'd Callapia, ſhe is a ſubtle Woman; I look upon the information with leſs concern, becauſe it came from her; perhaps ſhe has a mind to thee her ſelf: Ha, you bluſh! nay, then 'tis ſo indeed, the Wealth ſhe ſhewed thee has ſeduc'd thy Heart from Bebbemeah, which makes you ſo eaſily entertain an ill Opinion of her.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Sir, your Reproaches are too ſevere, and moſt unjuſt, I love fair Bebbemeah above my Life or Liberty, I'd rather live a wandering Fugitive, by all but her forſaken than ſit on the bright Throne of our great Siam's King without her: Callapia, Sir, cannot by any means ſeduce my faithful Heart, tho I muſt own ſhe has endeavoured it.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Then baniſh all thy Doubts, and take thy Bebbemeah to thy Boſom, 'tis all Deſign, where's thy Senſe, that thou doſt not perceive it?

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: I would moſt willingly believe it ſo, but ſure ſhe could not be ſo very wicked without ſome Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Is not that Cauſe enough? Go, go, and find thy Bebbemeah out, a ſight of her will quite diſpel thy Fears.

div.stage: As he is going out Callapia's Woman meets him and whiſpers him.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Callapia ſpeak with me! tell her I'le wait on her. Aſide Perhaps 'tis to confeſs the Wrong ſhe has done, I'le go whate'er it be. Exit Munz.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p:
(alone) I ever ſince Pechai's death have had a ſuſpicion of his being poiſon'd, he died with all the Signs, and much I fear Callapia's Hand was in it, I muſt examin when firſt her Love begun to Munzuffer, that might be the cauſe of his untimely End, and all her Grief
diſſembl'd to palliate her Crime; the Reſolution too of burning might be the ſame, for well ſhe knew ſhe ſhould be ſav'd: Here comes her Daughter, for once I'le liſten, I may diſcover ſomething by it. abſconds

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I am denied admittance to Bebbemeah's Chamber, what's the meaning of't I know not, but much I fear ſome foul Play's deſign'd. My Mother ſent for her to come to her Apartment: Cemat too I met in haſte going to Callapia, I would have ſpoke to him, but could not make him ſtay, ſuch was his haſte: And juſt now I ſee Munzuffer enter my Mother's Lodgings; there muſt be ſomething in't, good Heavens protect her, I know my Mother alwaies hated her.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: This is as I would have it; if they're all together, they'l quickly come to clearing the buſineſs; I hope ſhe does repent of what ſhe ſaid, and gives this meeting to reconcile the matter: Choufera may perhaps interrupt 'em, I'le divert her ſome other way. ſhews himſelf. Choufera, I have ſome buſineſs, pray let me talk with you.

div.stage: Takes her Hand, leads her off.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: (aſide) O my confuſion! I fear he knows I love his charming Son. Enter Munzuffer and Callapia.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I ſent for you, Munzuffer, to let you know your Bebbemeah, whom you'r ſo fond of, has given up her right in you to me, and ſays ſhe loves you not, nor ever did, and is reſolv'd to give her ſelf to my Son Cemat: Now, Munzuffer, ſee who loves you beſt, and be not ſtill ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: How can you ſay you love me, Madam, and find ſo many ways to torture me? I'm ſure 'tis falſe, ſhe did confeſs to me her ſelf ſhe lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: She told you ſo indeed ſhe ſaid, but 'twas to pleaſe her Father, ſhe now is Miſtreſs of her ſelf, and will not be impoſed on in her Choice; ſhe added likewiſe, if you diſtruſted what I ſaid, ſhe'd tell you ſo her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: If ſhe does that, I'le never trouble her again; I ſhall not think her worth the asking for.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I'le lead you to her Chamber, if ſhe's there, you'l be convinc'd that what I ſay is true. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene draws, diſcovers Beb. aſleep on a Couch, with a black Slave in her Arms. Enter at another Door Munzuffer and Callapia.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Ha! what do I ſee! ſure 'tis Deluſion all, I dare not truſt my ſight; good Gods, can that be Bebbemeah!

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Infamous Girl! this was an unexpected ſight, but now, I hope, you are convinc'd of my Truth and her Diſloyalty. Call runs to the Couch, and kills the Black with a Dagger. Dye, ſawey Slave, it is not fit thou ſhouldſt outlive ſo foul a Crime to boaſt of. The Slave falls dead from off the Couch, at which Beb. wakes.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (riſing) Ha, where am I? what means this Blood upon my Garments?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Lock there, laſcivious Girl, and ſee by me your black Amorat ſlain.

sp.speaker: Beb
sp.p: Mine! Heavens, what d'ye mean? this is ſome Plot upon my Honour: ſay, Munzuffer, ſure you will tell me truth, how came all this to paſs? how came I here, you, and Callapia, and that poor wretch who lies weltring in his Blood?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (aſide to Munz.) Obſerve her great concern for him.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Sure 'tis no wonder, Madam, to find you in your own Apartment, but to be found in the Embraces of a poor Slave, who you muſt court to ſatisfie your Luſt, think, think on that, falſe Bebbemeah.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: How Munzuffer! do you conſpire againſt me too? you cannot ſure believe ſo foul a thought of me.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (to Mun.) I muſt confeſs I oft have heard of this, and tho' I told you of it, I ne'er before was an Eye-witneſs of her Infamy; O, I am ſick with Grief and Shame for this lewd Proſtitute, I can bear the ſight of her no longer. Exit Call.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: O Bebbemeah! is it poſſible that heavenly Form, ſurpriſing Fair, ſhould hide ſo black a Soul? had the great Rulers of the enamel'd Sky deſcended and told me this, I would not have believ'd 'em; but with my own Eyes wide open, to thy ſhame, to view thy luſtful Sin, there is not one bare Hope left me, that I might be deceiv'd. Adieu. Going, ſhe takes hold of him.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O ſtay and hear me ſpeak; I am ruin'd and betray'd, by whom or by what means I cannot tell; how that Wretch came here, by all the ſacred Powers, I know not, I'm truly innocent, my dear Munzuffer, believe me ſo, or I am loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Did not I ſee your fair white Arms lay twin'd about that ſooty fellow's Neck, and all that melting lovely Body in his black luſtful Arms? is this to be forgiven by a young Lover, who almoſt died each day for the enjoyment of that Treaſure a poor deſpis'd Slave has rob'd thee of?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I do not ask Forgiveneſs Munzuffer, I have not committed any Crime that needs it.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: O monſtrous! not a Crime to be found in the Arms of a black loathſom Slave! Gets from her, and is going.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: This barbarous Uſage to me you'l repent, Heaven, who of Innocence take care, will clear the wrong you do my Virtue; you cannot entertain, I'm ſure, ſo vile a Thought of your once-lov'd Bebbemeah: You ſhall not leave me till you believe me, He offers to go, ſhe catches hold of him on her knees, and follows him as ſhe ſpeaks. as I am moſt innocent of this black Crime you unjuſtly charge me with.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Why would you keep me with you, Madam, you've given your Intereſt up in me to be another's Right.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I give my Intereſt up! what is't you mean? I ſee the Powers of Hell are all conſpir'd to ruine Bebbemeah; my dear-lov'd Lord, hear and believe my Vows: May ne'er the Sun's all-cheering Light appear to my benighted Eyes, but an eternal Darkneſs alwaies cover me; may this poor Body, which you once did love, be the living Prey of Lions, Bears, or Tygers; and all the Hopes I ever had for Happineſs, prove endleſs Curſes to me, if e'er my Heart, ſo much as in one Thought, ſtray'd from you ſince firſt you took the ſole poſſeſſion there. And for this horrid Injury you do my ſpotleſs Fame, may I unpitied die, loath'd and abhor'd by all, and leave an everlaſting Scandal on my Name to all ſucceeding Ages, if e'er a Deed ſo foul was known to the chaſte Soul of the much-wrong'd Bebbemeah.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: My Heart pleads ſtrongly, and I would believe thee, but 'tis impoſſible, did not I ſee thy Falſhood my ſelf; I'le hear no more, farewel for ever. Going, ſhe holds him.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p:
You muſt, you ſhall believe me, I will not let you go till I have quite drove out this black Suſpicion from your noble Soul. He breaks from her, which pulls her on the groud, and exit. O, can I hold no longer, he's gone, he's gone, here I will lye and never riſe again; Oh, kindeſt Mother Earth! open, and in thy Bowels hide my everlaſting Shame, ſwallow me deep into the Center, that no Remains be ever found of wretched Bebbemeah, to put the World in mind that once there was ſuch an unhappy Maid. (pauſes and weeps) Ha! I have found out now the whole Deſign! The Wealth Callapia ſhew'd has corrupted him, and this a Trick of both for a Pretence to break our Marriage off: ungenerous man! was it not Injuſtice enough to break thy Vows, but ſacrifice my Fame to thy Perfidiouſneſs? curſt,
curſed Gold, what mighty Evil is it that thou haſt not done?

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Ha, Bebbemeah! my deareſt Siſter, why in this poſture, and why that Face and Voice of Sorrow? Runs to take her up.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: No, Choufera, let me lye on this cold Bed, like Byblis, I would weep my ſelf into a ſtreaming Fountain: O Siſter, cou'd you think it! I'm betray'd by thy falſe Mother and falſer baſe Munzuffer; they found me here (by what means they beſt can tell, I'm ſure I cannot) in that murder'd Monſter's Arms; can you, Choufera, believe me ſuch a Proſtitute? if you forſake me too, I am abandon'd by all the World.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: No, Bebbemeah, I never will forſake thee, but like a Friend indeed, partake of all thy wretched Fortune: Treacherous Man! would he not hear thee plead thy Innocence?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: He gave no credit to all that I could ſay; no, no, thy Mother, by a Wealth ſhe has unknown to thee, has charm'd his avaricious Mind, and ſnatch'd his Heart from me.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Stay not in this moſt unlucky place, poor ruin'd Bebbemeah, fly to ſome private corner of the World, where we will end our days together, and ne'er be heard of more.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (riſing) It ſhall, it ſhall be ſo, I'le go for ever from the fight of this falſe perjur'd Man, but you, my deareſt only Friend, muſt ſtay to right, if poſſible, my blaſted Reputation; I have a Maid who long has waited on me, whoſe Faith and Love I've had ſufficient Proof of, I'le take her with me.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I never can conſent to leave thee in ſuch Miſery, I'le follow and ſhare thy mighty Sorrow, it never ſhall be ſaid Choufera forſakes her Bebbemeah when moſt ſhe has need of Comfort.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Or will I e'er involve my deareſt Friend in my unheard of Woes. Enter Sardea.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O Madam! fly from this fatal place; I juſt now heard deſigns are laid againſt your deareſt Life; Callapia's Woman has undertaken, by her perſwaſion, to poyſon you, which ſhe conſented to, to hinder employing ſome one elſe that might perform her deviliſh Commands; ſhe came and told me of it, to give you timely Warning.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Moſt wicked Woman! I will not call thee Mother.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Yet I would not ſo tamely die, and leave an everlaſting Blot upon my Name; What ſhall I do, Sardea, or whither ſhall I go?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Cloſe by the Menam's ſide, on Levo's Plain, there is a Houſe the People whereof I know very well, there you may be conceal'd till we can find a Veſſel to tranſport us further.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Till then I'le here remain, and give you daily information of all that paſſes; but go no further I charge thee, Bebbemeah, without Choufera with thee.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (kiſſes her) Bring all my Jewels, Sardea, I may have uſe of'em. And now, my Choufera, adieu; my ſad Heart bodes I ne'er ſhall ſee thee more. Exit Sardea, returns with a Corket.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Take not this ſolemn Leave, I'le ſee thee e're I ſleep.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: This poor perfidiouſneſs of baſe Munzuffer has almoſt cur'd my Paſſion for him; but ſtill I am unhappy, to be the Daughter of ſuch a wicked Mother, 'tis my deareſt Siſter's Calamities that now afflict me moſt. Enter Sennorat.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Where is this injur'd Lady, this abuſed Bebbemeah?

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Where indeed, moſt generous Lord, 'tis noble in you to vindicate oppreſt and helpleſs Virtue; ſhe's gone, I know not where, to voluntary Exile.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: O mad, raſh, fooliſh Boy! thou'ſt thrown away a Treaſure never perhaps to be recover'd; this was Callapia's doings, wicked Woman! forgive me, Lady I had forgot ſhe is your Mother.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: I wiſh I could forget it too, but I diſown all Duty to her, who has forgot her ſelf and Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: So, Sir! you're come to triumph, are you, at the fine piece of work your raſhneſs has cut out; you've ſent your Bebbemeah from you ne'er to be recal'd; there now remains no Obſtacle, you'd beſt take your Callapia, the contriver of all this fatal miſchief, (angrily) but if you do, I charge you never ſee me more, and may an angry Father's Curſe ſtill follow thee; I hope ſhe will reward you as you deſerve for your Credulity. Exit Sennorat, Choufera offers to go.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay Choufera, and tell me what my angry Father means and where's Bebbemeah; I do begin to think we both have been abus'd, and I to blame.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: To blame indeed, unfaithful man! you know her Innocence too well, and ſhou'd you now repent, ſhe's gone beyond the reach of hearing thy Remorſe, and by thy treacherous Vows, broken to Heaven and her, will never be deluded more. Exit Chouf.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: If, Bebbemeah, thou art guiltleſs, what an unhappy man has loſt Munzuffer made himſelf!

lg.l: Reveal, kind Heaven, (if ſo ſhe be) her Truth and my Offence;
My Blood ſhall expiate the wrong is done her Innocence. Exit Munz.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Scene the Plain of Levo, a little Country-houſe at a ſmall diſtance.

sp.speaker: Mut
sp.p: WHY where's this Chavo? the Fool is alwaies out o'th' way whan he ſhou'd be doing himzelf good.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Look'e now, you're ſo haſty a Dog won't live with you, as the Saying is, call him all to naught preſently, tho' you know not wherefore; he's gone to put on his Holiday clothes, I hope you wou'd not have you fine Gentlewoman ſee him in his Every-day Gere, wou'd you trow?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: No, no, I'm pacified, a word to the wiſe; but this poor Gentlewoman is huge molloncholy, Metam, can you tell what ails her, or who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: No truly, not I, but Sardea ſays 'tis her Siſter, tho' I don't believe it, ſhe's ſo much finer and handſomer; poor Heart, ſhe takes on pitifully, it makes a bodies Heart yern to hear her; ſhe ſighs and crys, and won't tell what the matter's with her, and won't eat one bit of Victuals.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Well, I hope our Sports will make her merry; but why don't this Boy come? one might a cut half a Field of Rice in the time he's bin dreſſing, wou'd I war behind him, I'd make him a little quicker.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Lord Husband, you have no forecaſt with you, let him have time to ſmug himſelf a little, you don't know but the young Gentlewoman may caſt a Sheeps-eye upon him, and like him; Chavo's as pretty a Stripling as any's in forty mile an end, when he'as his beſt Clothes on. Sardea may ſay what ſhe will, but I warrant her huge rich, ſhe'as a Box full of the braveſt ſhining things I e'er ſee all days of my Life, 'twou'd e'en make a-bodies Eyes dazle to look on 'em: O Muto, if we could get her in the mind to have our Chavo, 'twou'd be the making of us all; and, who knows but we may ride in our Palankeens as well as the beſt?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Away, away you fool, ſuch a fine Gentlewoman look upon our Son! why I warrant ſhe ne'er milk'd a Cow in all her Life, and knows no more how to fat our Pullen than the Man in the Moon.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: For that matter, ſhe'd quickly learn. O, here comes Chavo, do but ſee, Husband, how pure handſom he looks.

div.stage: Enter Chavo, powder'd all over ridiculouſly.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Hei, hei! handſom, kether! ſure ſomebody has been rouling him in the Rice; ſirrah, you a ſpoil'd your clothes. offers to beat it off.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Nay, what de do, Faather? now to zee your ignorance, why 'tis all the faſhion, man; it came over from England with the laſt Ship came in here, there's no-body look'd upon that is not bedon zo; nay, they zay the fine Ladies like it ſo hugeouſly, they powder their Dogs and Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Nay, nay, an 'tis the faſhion, well and good, I'm contented.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Well, but where's thiz hanzom Gentlewoman? ſhaunt I zee her? adzfleſh, I want to be at her, as a body may zay.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Fair and ſoftly Son at her, marry gap, pray keep your diſtance, and make a fine Leg every time you ſpeak to her; beſure you behave your ſelf handſomly.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Why what a-pies, iz ſhe made of, muſten ſhe be tucht? zure a Man may buſs her, az a body may zay, and no harm dun.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Hark'e, Sirrah, don't you be zawcy, but keep your Buſſes to your ſelf you'd beſt, ſhe may be angry, and leave us in a pett, and then what ſhall we get by your Buſſes?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Well, well, if I muſſent I muſſent, what a coil is here about a Buſs! marry, I've laid o'er the Lips as good as ſhe, and no diſparagement to her: Are all the Slaves come up? when muſt we begin? I long to be at it. ſhakes his Legs.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Not till ſhe come, 'twont be long firſt.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Here's a heavy fuſs with her; an now if ſhe wont have a body, after all, why then all the Fat's in the Fire again.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Adzfleſh, is this ſhe? ſhe's terrible hanzom indeed, I long to be at her; odſnigs, I have much ado to keep my Advances towards her, cringing and making legs, Bebbemeah looks at him, and turns to Sardea. Hands off from her. Goodluck a day, how ſcornful ſhe looks! I'le be as ſtout as ſhe, and then perhaps ſhe'l be more coming. Retreats.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Why doſt thou bring me here, Sardea? ſuch Woes as mine are not to be aleviated by Muſick, I have no taſt of any of their Sports, no Sound is grateful to my bleeding Heart, but the ſad note of mourning Philomel, or the repining voice of diſcontented Eccho: I would not ſee any thing that bears the Shape of faithleſs Man.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
They'l take't unkindly, Madam, ſhould you refuſe to ſee their Entertainment, they mean it well to pleaſe you, ſeem ſo however, —
you know we have uſe of them as long as as we ſtay here, and therefore muſt oblige 'em.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (to Met.) Why, what's the matter, trow? is ſhe in her pouts?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: No, no, ſhe's hougely diſcontented, poor Soul; I know not what the matter's with her, go and ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.l: Nay, nay, and that be all, let me alone for ſpeaking. goes to her.
You're welcome to our Houſe, forſooth, az a body may zay.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: This is our Landlord's Son, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Thank you, Friend.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Thank you, Friend, is that all? Adzfleſh, I'll to her again for all that: You're woundy fine methinks, Miſtreſs; Do you wear theſe fine Clothes every day? you'd need have a power of Mony to buy ſuch coſtly Gere. Looks all round her.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I'm glad you like it.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Like it korher, I never zee the like in all my born days, not I; but for all that, the beſt piece is in the middle, as a body may zay: Odſnigs, if you'd but like me half zo well, I'd quickly ſet you out of your dumps.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Sure Fortune deſigns me for her Sport. turns from him. Pray learn your Son more Manners, I ſhall be angry elſe.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Sarrah, learn more Reſpect to the Gentlewoman, or I'le ſo belabour you, I'le make you feel it this two days.

sp.speaker: Chav.
