sp.p: Nay, an ſhe be ſo proud, I can keep my diſtance an that be all; I won't come near you again mun, if you'd kiſs — Adzfleſh, what was I going to zay!

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Pray forſooth don't take pleaſure in his words, he dus not mean any harm to you, 'tis for want of Wit and Mannors.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Marry an you'd need talk of that too, 'tiz az you've taught me, and who's the Fool then? but I meant no harm, by Jingo, not I; I only zay you're a woundy hanſom Gentlewoman, an I hope that's no Offence; but I warant I pleaz you again when we come to daunce, there's ne'er a Lad on all the Plain can outdo me, tho' I zay it that ſhouldn't; nay, and I can zing too, marry can I.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I do not queſtion it.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Then why ar you zo ſtout? Ar you angry becauſe a body loves you? or is it becauſe you're zo much finer than I? Adsfleſh, if you'd but let me lye with you two or three Nights, you'd love me too; the Hogs love by lying together.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: (holds up his Stick) Sarrah, you will not leave your prating till I ſee old Crabtree about your Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: What, would you have a body ſtand like Mumchance, az if I didn't know better than your old mouldy Chops how to car my zelf to a Gentlewoman; 'tis the faſhion to talk a great deal, tho' never zo little to the purpoſe, an if you don't like't, you may leave it, an that be all.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Prithee Sardea, let me not be tortur'd with that Fool's Impertinence, I have more weighty Thoughts to entertain than his ridiculous Folly.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: Are the Dancers ready Chavo? I long to ſee you begin.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: May be thay ar, may be thay ant, I'd a told her pointing to Beb. an ſhe'd ask'd me.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: And why won't you tell me?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Becauſe you ant half ſo hanſom as ſhe; you may be angry too an you will, I don't care.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: Ay, but Chavo, I can ſpeak a good word for you to your Miſtreſs, you know ſhe's my Siſter, and will follow my Advice.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Marry, an you will, I'll give you the beſt Flock of Sheep my Faather haz.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: Well, ſay no more, you ſhall ſee what I'le do if you will but begin.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: An zo we will then preſently, (whiſtles.) and that will fet 'em, I warrant ye, if they war ne'er zo far a field: Now mind how purely I wag my Legs, you never zee the like man, I can tell you that.

lg.l: I'le daunce and zing, and do my beſt to win her,
An if ſhe won't be pleas'd, the Devil's in her.

div.stage: Enter Men and Women, dance after the Indian manner: Chavo joins with 'em.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: You zee forſooth we be merry Folks, how de like this Sport, az a body may zay?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: You dance and ſing to a Miracle Chavo.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p:
'Tis your pleaſure to zay zo, but I think I do pretty well for one of my inches; Adzfleſh, we'l make you az merry az a Cricket if you do but ſtay amongſt us a little while, az a body may zay: But I can do more than this mun, I can pitch the Bar, play at Cat and Cudgels, and wraſtle with e'er a one in a good way; I'le try a Fall with
you an you will forſooth. Puts his Hair behind his Ears, and ſets himſelf in a poſture for wreſtling.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: De think Gentlewomen uſe to wraſtle, you Boobee you?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Marry, an ſhe may e'en do worſe, as the Zong zays; but you ar ſo given to call a body ill Names, if you wan't my Faather, adzfleſh, I'd crack your Conundrum for you; no more a Boobee than zomebody elſe, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I thank you all for this Divertion, I know 'twas ſo deſign'd, I hope I ſhall not give Offence to any, if I retire to my Chamber, I have ſome Buſineſs to diſpatch requires my bei • g alone; come Sardea.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (to Sard.) Will you remember your Promiſe?

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: Never fear it, I'le do your buſineſs for you. Ex. Beb. & Sar.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (aſide) Now an I can get this brave Gentlewoman, I'll have no more to zay to theſe old folks, let 'em e'en look another Zon for Chavo, I'le diſown 'em when I grow rich, az 'tiz the faſhion, for fear of being put in mind of my Pedigree.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: So Sarrah, hant you carr'd your ſelf finely, perhaps ſhe's angry, and will leave our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Marry an let her be pleas'd again for Chavo, muſten ſhe be lookt upon? 'tis all long of your niggardlineſs; you might ha' let me had zome new Clothes to a gone a ſuitoring in; you may e'en thank your zelf, what de tell me of it for?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Come Metam, let's go and get the beſt Cheer we can for her Supper, poor Soul, ſhe'as eat nothing ſince ſhe came.

sp.speaker: Chav.

lg.l: Well, I reſolve to try what may be done,
Fair Lady with faint Heart war never won. Ex. Chav.

div.stage: Scene Callapia's Houſe. Enter Callapia and Cemat.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
To 'ſcape me thus, when all my Plots were ripe for execution! I'm all Confuſion at it; ſhould ſhe return, I'm ruin'd for ever in all
Deſigns upon Munzuffer, Sennorat moſt zealouſly pleads for her Innocence, his Son, I hear, inclines to think her ſo, and is deaf to all the Overtures I make him; Sennorat is my deadly Enemy, and does ſuſpect me of my Husband's Death, I muſt not ſuffer ſuch Thoughts to grow upon him, but nip'em in the Bud, take the old Dotard off, and ſpoil his thinking.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: You're blinded with your Paſſion, and thirſt of Bebbemeah's Blood; 'tis better as it is, for had you effected your Deſigns upon her Life, you would have been believ'd to be the Cauſe; and think what Hopes you then muſt e'er have had of your Munzuffer's Love: She's ſafe enough, where-e'er ſhe is, from returning hither again, her flight was voluntary, and the ſame Reaſon that caus'd it will keep her from coming back: Try all the fair means poſſible to gain Munzuffer, no other way will do, Force cannot compel him to marry you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: If Bebbemeah never does return, her Fortune falls to me; or if ſhe does, I'le take ſuch care ſhe never ſhall enjoy it: Can I before but poſſeſs my ſelf of dear Munzuffer, I then will happy be in ſpight of Fate, and triumph o'er the Miſchief I have done; her Wealth added to what I have already, would tempt a King to falſifie a Vow made even at the Altar: I'le find him inſtantly, and will not leave till I have made him mine, if poſſible; but if he ſtill perſiſts in his Ingratitude, I will not longer bear his Scorn, he ſhall be mine or no ones elſe, by Heavens. Going.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Stay Madam, you forget that Bebbemeah was the Reward you promis'd for my Services.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Why find her if you can, and take her, you would not have me ſeek her for you, perhaps ſhe's conceal'd in ſome of the neighbouring Villages, you'l do well to ſearch.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: You know I do not value her, nay, hate her for her ſcorn of me, it is her Fortune, Madam, that I'd have, and do expect; conſider if I do not well deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Truſt to thy Mother's Care, Cemat, I'le ſee thee well provided for, thou doſt deſerve more than I have to give thee.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam, but I will not truſt your Care or Courteſie, I claim it as my Due; I find you do reſerve it all to promote your own Happineſs, and ne'er take care of mine.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
Why art thou ſo miſtruſtful of thy Mother's Love? it ſhall be all thine whene'er I die, and whilſt I live thou ſhalt command at all times what thou wilt: Be ſatisfied, I will moſt largely recompence
thy Services, let me but make Munzuffer mine, thou then ſhalt ſhare in all things thou canſt wiſh.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Think not to put thoſe Tricks on me you have to all beſide, I know you too well to be my ſelf deceiv'd; there's nothing ſhall or will content me, but putting all Bebbemeah's Wealth into my preſent poſſeſſion; you will not do diſcreetly to refuſe me, you know your Life is in my power, I would not willingly betray you, but yet I will (like you) ſacrifice all things to my Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (aſide) Say you ſo, raſh Fool, 'tis time then to diſpatch thee: To him You cannot betray me, but you involve your ſelf in Ruine with me.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: No fear for that, I will ſecure my ſelf, therefore give me the Promiſe under your own Hand, or elſe this very minute I will diſcover all your wicked Practiſes.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Come to my Cloſet half an hour hence, and there I'le make it entirely over to thee, and more than thou deſireſt.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Swear then, As e'er you hope for Happineſs with Munzuffer; I know no other Oath will bind you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I do, and wiſh I never may enjoy him, if I do not make thee Maſter of all the Wealth that's Bebbemeah's before to morrow dawn, Aſide which thou ſhalt never ſee.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I now believe you, and if you have further uſe of the Hand and Heart of your obliged Son, you may command.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I ſhall employ you, come, as I ſaid, to my Cloſet half an hour hence, I have a new Deſign a foot I then will tell you of, Aſide. which is for thy deſtruction, Fool. Exit Call.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I will be ſure to wait on you. So, now I may with reaſon hope I've ſecur'd Bebbemeah's Fortune, which ſhe dare not refuſe me; I'm pleas'd to think how very potent I ſhall be in wickedneſs; I muſt and will enjoy my Lovely Siſter, but firſt I'le after my pious Mother, ſhe's hatching ſome new Project, I wiſh it be but wicked enough, and when I've gotten what ſhe promis'd, if I can reap advantage by it any other way, I will betray her; Honour and Honeſty are ſtarving Qualities, 'tis only Wickedneſs that thrives in this bleſt Age; I own no Powers but Almighty Gold, that, that's the Idol of my Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p:
I'm all Diſtractions if I have thus raſhly thrown away the Bleſſing of my Life, what will become of the miſerable Munzuffer?
Yet, oh! it cannot be, theſe Eyes beheld the fatal ſight, they could not be deceiv'd; I will recover my loſt Peace again, why ſhould I thus diſturb my ſelf for one not worth the wracking of my Soul? ſhe's falſe, and I will ſtudy to forget her.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Unſtable Boy! did you not ſay juſt now you did believe her blameleſs, and that you would ſeek her through the World to beg her Pardon?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I know not Sir, alas, what I think my ſelf, my Mind's ſo diſcompos'd.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Think, as you'l in time find true, it was a helliſh Trick of Callapia; has ſhe not ſince ſpread all the Snares ſhe thinks will catch thee? I charge thee, on my Bleſſing, think not of her; if thou doſt conſent to marry her, I will renounce thee from that hour, and wiſh thee alwaies wretched.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Marry her! I'd rather be condemn'd to endleſs Slavery, and never taſte of Liberty again, than have a Thought of ſuch a thing; I hate her worſe than Death, nay, much more, for that would be welcome now, I wiſh I could forget all the vaſt Troubles of my Mind in an eternal Sleep.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Munzuffer, ſay not ſo, for thou maiſt live to a long Age of Joys, thy Fortunes yet are not ſo deſperate, but we may find a Salve to heal them all, if Bebbemeah's Innocence appears, thy Trouble's at an end; conſider all the ways Callapia has taken to bring thee to her Luſt, and think if ſhe would ſtick at any thing to effect it, ſhe knew it was impoſſible while Bebbemeah reign'd, and this was a Contrivance to drive her from you.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: How ſhou'd a Slave be admitted to her Apartment without her knowledge, and found within her Arms?

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Moſt eaſily; it was not an hour before you went thither her wicked Mother ſent for her, Choufera told me ſo, and ſaid withal, ſhe fear'd ſome foul Play was deſign'd her.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir! O, now I do remember the very time, ſhe likewiſe ſent for me, and by a Trick carried me to her Chamber to find her in that poſture; too late I ſee it muſt be ſo: O injur'd lovely Lady! where ſhall I find thee out, to ſhew my Penitence? Choufera ſure can tell, I ne'er will leave her till ſhe does, I'le fly with Lovers Wings, to implore her Pardon, which I too juſtly fear ſhe ne'r will grant to the guilty Munzuffer. (going) Ha, did you ſpeak Sir? a Voice under the Stage cries, guilty Munzuffer.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: No, but heard a Voice, from whence I cannot tell, it repeated your laſt words.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Sure it was our Fancy, here's no one near us, I hope 'tis Bebbemeah's good Angel, ſent to clear her Innocence. Again Sir, did you not hear it? Voice cries, Clear her Innocence.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I did, and am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: O tell me, gentle Spirit, if ſuch thou be, where I ſhall find my much-wrong'd Bebbemeah. Voice cries, Much-wrong'd Bebbemeah. 'Tis ſo, 'tis ſo, the Gods in pity to my Sufferings have ſent to clear her of thoſe black Detractions unjuſtly caſt upon her. Voice cries, Detractions unjuſtly caſt upon her. Tell me, I charge thee, is ſhe innocent? Voice, ſhe's innocent. 'Tis nothing but an Eccho ſure that catches my laſt words, and I only flatter my ſelf into a belief of what I'd have ſo; if thou art any thing beſide a Voice, appear, and tell me if Callapia is the cauſe of all this fatal miſchief. Voice, Callapia is the cauſe of all this fatal miſchief.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: If thou'rt a human ſhape, I do invoke thee, by the God you ſerve, to ſhew thy ſelf. The Spirit aſcends.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: This is the very ſame that gave me warning of my enſuing Troubles.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: FOllow, follow, follow me,
Thy Enemies at jarrs thou't ſee:
Be thankful Youth, the Gods take care
Thy Doubts and Jealouſies to clear:
Follow, follow, follow me,
The Myſtery ſhall unravel'd be.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Go where thou wilt, I'le follow thee.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: And I'le not ſtay behind.

sp.speaker: Mun
sp.l: My Guilt in her wrong'd Virtue does appear;
Heaven of the Innocent, I find, takes care.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Scene a Proſpect of the Country.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I Muſt not now loſe time in hearing thy weak Arguments, the Penitence you inſiſt upon was the only means to get you in my power, and now you are, you ſhall not 'ſcape again.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Heavens! what will become of me!

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Not Heaven or Hell ſhall take you from me now.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Yonder he is, and Choufera with him, I muſt keep an Eye upon him till he's ſafe from telling Tales, the working of the Poiſon may make him rave, and in his Frenzy diſcover all he knows; I muſt remove her from him, it is not ſafe that ſhe ſhould ſee him die.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: (pulling Chouf) This way a little further is a private place fit for my purpoſe. ſhe ſtrives to get from him. Nay, nay, no drawing back nor Outcries, 'tis to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? good Heaven ſend me ſome aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Ha! the Villain's forcing her to his hot Luſt! ſhews her ſelf. O monſtrous Cemat! what, raviſh thy own Siſter!

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Nay, now I've loſt all hopes indeed, but ſince I can't enjoy her, no other ſhall. Stabs Choufera, who falls.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: O barbarous, inhuman, bloody Man! ſpeak, my Choufera, to thy afflicted Mother.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: He'as given me my Death, but I forgive him, and beg you'd do ſo too. Swoons.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Ha! what ails me? ſure I am not well, my Head grows giddy, and my Eyes are dim; my Body trembles, ſure 'tis not what they call remorſe, I find none in my Heart.

div.stage: Enter Sennorat and Munzuffer following the Spirit, the Spirit waves a Wand over them.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.p: Stand there, you're inviſible ſo long as you are ſilent. deſcends

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: No, Fool, thou haſt the juſt Reward of this moſt horrid deed, thou'rt poyſon'd by thy Mother, you drank your laſt in that dire Cordial I gave you in my Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: Hell thank you for it, Fury and Vengeance direct me to ſink her with me to the black Kingdom where my Soul is going. Plings a Dagger at her, but miſſes her, ſhe takes it up. Curſe of my feeble Arm, it will not do; is this the Thanks you give your Son for being the Inſtrument in murdering your Husband, and betraying Bebbemeah?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Did not you tell me my Life was in your power? how cou'd you think I'd tamely bear your Threats?

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, for fear ſhe 'ſcapes my Vengeance give your aſſiſtance to poor Choufera, while I ſecure the Murdereſs.

div.stage: Callapia looks back, cries out as ſurpriz'd, runs to ſtab Cemat, but is prevented by Senn. who takes the Dagger up. Munz. goes to Chouf. and holds her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: She's only in a Swoon with loſs of Blood, I hope her wound's not mortal.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: See Munzuffer, this is the very Villain we reſcued Choufera from before; is't poſſible, good Heaven, you could attempt your Siſter's Honour?

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: I have no time to anſwer idle Queſtions, if I can rally but Strength enough to perfect my Revenge upon my unnatural Mother there, I'le die contented. She had from me a Doſe, which ſhe gave Pechai, and that did his buſineſs; and by a ſleeping Potion given to both Bebbemeah and the Slave, it was contriv'd by her, that Munzuffer ſhould ſee 'em as they lay; how ſhe effected it I need not tell you, and did deſign her Death, had not her flight prevented: I was by Covenant to have her Fortune, for my aſſiſtance to her, which baſely ſhe refus'd; I threaten'd to betray her, for which ſhe'as recompenc'd me as you ſee, I can no more. ſtaggers and falls.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: He raves, 'tis falſe as Hell each Syllable he utters.

sp.speaker: Cem.
sp.p: O whither am I going! ſtand off, foul Fiend: O Horror, Horror! I dare not die, I ſee Hell gape, and all the Devils with their forked Spears ſtand ready to receive me; grim Pluto too ſits in his fiery Throne, and laughs at my Amazement: Help, help! they drag me down, oh! Dies.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: You ſee, my Lord, how the juſt Gods abhor the Imputation he has laid on me, by the diſturbance of his Mind juſt at the point of death.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: No, barbarous Lady, that will not clear your Guilt, we heard you own your Wickedneſs your ſelf, no ſly Evaſions now ſhall ſerve your turn, I will commit you to the Hands of Juſtice, and proſecute you with utmoſt Rigour, the poyſoning your Son is Crime enough to die for.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: The Injury he offer'd to his Siſter deſerv'd no leſs than death. I found him offering Violence to her Virgin-honour, and when he ſee he was ſurpriz'd in his Attempt, he ſtab'd her; ask Choufera if it is not Truth.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: The Draught was given him in your Cloſet, Lady, you cannot ſhift it off, you muſt along with me, and ſhall have all the Juſtice done you that your Crime deſerves: Take care, Munzuffer, of that fair bleeding Lady, and if her Wound admits of any Cure, let nothing be ſpar'd for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Munzuffer, Daughter, will you not ſave me from this cruel Man? Exit Sennorat, forcing out Callapia.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p:
(revives) Ha! who was't call'd me from this Sleep of Death? Why did you bring me back to Life again to know more Miſery? it
was unkindly done: Where am I, in Munzuffer's Arms? Nay, then I will not live to be ſnatch'd from theſe Embraces: Alas, I need not ſay I will not, cold Death ſits buſie at my Heart, and I am going where I ſhall find an everlaſting end to all my Woes.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Dear Choufera, for Pity tell me where to find the injur'd Bebbemeah, your Brother with his lateſt Breath declar'd her ſo, accus'd himſelf and thy moſt barbarous Mother to be the cauſe of all this deadly miſchief.

sp.speaker: Chouf.
sp.p: Too credulous Munzuffer! that you cou'd believe her guilty of ſo black a Sin! but I'le not now upbraid you, the Remorſe you feel is Puniſhment enough, that Paper will direct you where to find her; I was going thither now, when my impious Brother, diſappointed of his brutiſh Luſt, did this bloody Deed: When you have reconcil'd your juſtly-angry Miſtreſs, ſometimes reflect on poor Choufera's Misfortunes, who (had ſhe liv'd) muſt alwaies have been unhappy; for, oh! before my Soul expires, take, take the long-hid Secret, that I love you, my dear Lord; permit me ſo to call you, ſince 'tis not many minutes I have left to repeat that charming ſound: O turn thoſe Eyes away, or I ſhall die with bluſhing. Comfort my Bebbemeah, for my untimely Death, I know ſo well ſhe lov'd me, 'twill grieve her much; commend me to her: my Buſineſs on Earth's done, and I have nothing elſe to do but die. Grieve not, Munzuffer, at my Death, it brings me what I wiſh, eternal Peace, an end of all my Miſery here, and boundleſs Pleaſure in the Elizian Fields, where we ſhall meet again: May you be bleſs'd in all things with your dear Bebbemeah; farewel: take this firſt, laſt, and chaſte Embrace from poor Choufera. embraces him. Thus, thus I die contented. (fainting) Haſte to find — dies.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: (riſing from her) She's gone, and much I fear I've been ſome cauſe of this fair Virgin's death, her Wound was not deep, and might have been recover'd, her broken Heart was the moſt mortal Blow: She bid me haſte to find, I know ſhe meant my Bebbemeah. Opens the Paper, and reads.

At Muto's Houſe, on the Levoan Plain, cloſe by the Menam's ſide; ſhe's there conceal'd: I know it well, 'tis not a full mile off, I will not ſleep till I attone her Anger. (To the Serv.] Convey with care that lovely Body home, where ſhe may have the Rites of Funeral, but let his lie a Prey to ſavage Beaſts to be devour'd, not ſo much Brutes as he.

lg.l: I'll fly with Lovers Wings, t' appeaſe the injur'd Fair,
And meet the juſt Reproaches of my angry Dear. Exit.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: What ſhall I tamely yield my Body to the Stake? I cannot, muſt not die, I've yet a Work to do I muſt not leave unfiniſh'd, I'le ſummon all the Devils to my aid, but I will compaſs it: Two Murders, what's that! 'twill hardly give me place in Hell fitting my quality, I'd have a Hecatomb of Ghoſts to attend me there: I'm griev'd for poor Choufera's death, and for Cemat's too, but 'tis becauſe I have him not to kill again; oh that the Villain had as many Lives as Hydra Heads, that I might ſtab him in each one, and be an Age in killing him.

sp.speaker: Ghoſt.
sp.p: Thou haſt not ſo long to live, moſt miſerable Woman! e're this to morrow thou ſha't be with me in endleſs Torment not to be expreſs'd, the juſt Reward of all thy horrid Crimes, thy fatal Thread is ſpun, and thy unalterable Doom pronounc'd.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Thou ly'ſt, curſt Wretch, thou ly'ſt. Pechai's Ghoſt appears.

sp.speaker: Pech. Gho.
sp.p: It is too true, and is decreed above in thoſe bleſt Courts where thou muſt never come, inhuman Murdereſs! O think, thou wretched Woman, on thy loſt Condition; think how you can bear the ſcorching Flames about your tender Limbs, which never never are to be extinguiſht; let thy Aſſociate there tell the Miſeries which attend thee, whilſt I return to my bleſt Habitation, and praiſe the Gods for their juſt Vengeance on thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Farewel, old godly Fool, I do not wiſh to come where I may have thy Company again.

sp.speaker: Cem. Gho.
sp.p: Thou't wiſh for any thing but what thou art condemn'd to, moſt unrelenting Sinner! Prometheus Vulture! Tantalus's Feaſt, or the Belides never finiſh'd Labour is all but Sport to what's reſerv'd for thee; think not I come to warn you to repent, 'tis now too late, deſpair and die, and be as curſt as I am. Deſcends.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (ſola) This ſure is all Deluſion; or be it real, it is too late, he ſays, for Penitence; nor cou'd I if I wou'd; but yet I find an unuſual Horror ſet heavy at my Heart when Death comes in my thoughts. (Pauſes a little) I will not think of it, be gone, all idle Fears, Fears of I know not what; if I muſt die, it ſhall not be alone, nor will I tamely ſuffer an ignominious death, no, as long as I am Miſtreſs of this, (ſhews a Dagger) I will, when I think fit, diſpoſe of my own Fate: Still, ſtill theſe Viſions trouble me, I would forget 'em, and think 'em only Dreams. — 'Twas nothing elſe, I find it; I am awake, they're all vaniſh'd, and I am my ſelf again.

lg.l: If in thoſe fiery Regions I muſt dwell,
I'le do ſuch things ſhall make me Queen of Hell. Ex. Cal.

div.stage: Scene the Plain, enter Bebbemeah and Sardea.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I wonder my Choufera does not come, has ſhe forgot forſaken Bebbemeah? Prithee Sardea ſing the Song you us'd to entertain me with.

lg.l: 'TWas on a fatal day by chance a lovely Swain I ſaw,
His graceful Mein and noble Air did my attention draw.
When on his Knees the timerous Youth did firſt my Pity move,
With tender Sighs and moving Tears he ſwore eternal love.
I ſoon believ'd what moſt I wiſh'd; for, ah too heedleſs Maid!
The eaſie Conqueſt he obtain'd my treacherous Eyes betray'd.
He gain'd the ſoft Confeſſion too from my unguarded Heart
In Tranſports all o'er extaſie, but all, alas, was Art;
For now the falſe forſworn forgets his Vows to Heaven and me;
Regardleſs of my Honour too, he boaſts his Perjury.
Ye Gods, if injur'd Innocence be your peculiar care,
Revenge my Wrongs on that falſe Man, and wounded Fame repair.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Adzfleſh, forſooth, yonder haz been a moſt heavy racket, by the zide of the Wood, there is a curious hanſom Gentlewoman lies as dead as a Herring, and bleeds like any ſtuck Pig.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Ha! what ſay you, a Lady kil'd! by what means do you know?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell that; for my part, I thought at firſt it waz you, methought ſhe waz az like you az if ſhe had been ſpit out of your Mouth, az a body may zay.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Did you ſee her? what was her Habit? O Sardea, Heaven ſend it is not Choufera; was any body with her?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: Zee her! I think I did, there was a great many fine Folks. (looking out) Look forſooth, here comes a brave fine Gentleman waz there, he'l tell you more I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: It is Munzuffer, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Sardea, let's be gone, I will not ſee that faithleſs man. going

div.stage: Enter Munzuffer, who ſtays her by the Garment, and kneels.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, fair injur'd Lady, thus low I humbly beg you'l hear the guilty Munzuffer ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Too well, falſe Man, you know the way to Bebbemeah's Heart, I muſt not will not hear you; you did deny to me when moſt I pleaded for it, remember that, thou perjur'd Man!

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (aſide) Hey toſs, what the duce is the matter w'em, trow?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I do too well, and many faults beſide: ſhe offers to go. You muſt not leave me thus, I have a Story to tell thee will ſhock thy tender Soul; we both have been betray'd.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Tell me, Munzuffer, is Choufera well? Ha, you look ſad and ſigh; anſwer me, I charge you, what is become of her, and by what means you found me here.

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (aſide) Now will I be hang'd if thiz iz not her Zweetheart that ſhe haz taken on zo for.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Forbear to hear what will encreaſe thy Grief to ſuch a weight too heavy to be born.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (angrily) Tell me, or I'll ſtay one moment and ne'r ſee thee more.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Since you will force me to be the unhappy Meſſenger of ſuch diſmal tydings, Choufera's killed by barbarous Cemat, the cauſe I'le take another time to tell; he is poyſon'd by his Mother, and before he died confeſt the wrong they had done your virtue and my love.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O my Choufera, my deareſt tender Siſter! 'tis I, unhappy Slave, have been the cauſe of all theſe ſad Misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: She expir'd within my Arms, bid me commend her to you, and comfort you for her untimely Fall.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Alas, what Comfort can I e'er receive for ſuch a Loſs! my only conſtant Friend on Earth is gone, I hope I ſhall not long remain behind her.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: O ſay not ſo, cruel Bebbemeah, thou haſt a Friend which ever will be yours; how ſhall I atone for my Offence? is it not poſſible you can forgive?

sp.speaker: Chav.
sp.p: (aſide) Ay, ay, 'tis zo, I find I ſhall be bob'd of my Miſtreſs az a body may zay.

sp.speaker: Beb.
Mun.
sp.p: What mean you Bebbemeah? my Callapia! I'd ſooner take a Witch, a Succubus, to my Arms: I do believe in Hell there is not ſuch another Fury.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Her Wealth, my Lord, will make you compenſation for all Perſonal Defects; and for her Mind, the blacker 'tis, the more like thee, perfidious Man. angrily.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: By Heaven you wrong me, Madam, her Wealth and her I equally contemn, I ever ſcorn her loathſom Love, which has created all theſe ſad Diſtractions; 'twill ſoon be ſeen how well I love her, the Murder of your Father is detected, done by her curſed Hand, for which ſhe is to die.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Mercileſs Woman! when ſhall I find an end to all my Sorrows? they ſtill encreaſe, and will at laſt o'erwhelm me. Angrily But you, my Lord, I find, come to make up your Breach with me, becauſe you are like to loſe your other Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Still worſe and worſe; all I can ſay to juſtifie my ſelf turns to my diſadvantage; may I for ever be depriv'd of you, the greateſt Curſe I can wiſh, if e'er I had a Thought of loving any elſe ſince the firſt moment that I ſee you; were that vile Creature which you unjuſtly tax me with Empreſs of all our wealthy Indies, I'd ſcorn her as I have already done.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: How can you hope I ever ſhould? all I could ſay you would not lend an Ear to.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Upbraid me not with what 'tis Death to hear; all my whole Life ſhall be a continued Service, to expiate that one Fault: I do not blame your Anger, you have juſt reaſon for it; the mighty Gods are pacified by Penitence, and all I now dare ask is only your forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Suppoſe, my Lord, I ſhould, you do not think I e'er will put my ſelf in that man's power who could ſo eaſily believe ſo poorly of my Virtue? I need not ſay I will not, I do not find you do deſire it: You ſay you wiſh for nothing but Forgiveneſs; you have it, Sir. Now I ſuppoſe I may be gone, you've nothing elſe to ask.

div.stage: going, he takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Still, Madam, you reproach me with the only Blot I ever was aſham'd of; I do indeed deſerve your utmoſt Rigour, but O, unkind it is to ſay I've nothing elſe to ask! I have a mighty Boon, too much for you to give or me to crave; my Wiſhes are unbounded, but ſtill they center all in Bebbemeah. Think if the hoarding Miſer would be pleas'd to have his Coffers rifled, and all his Idol Gold thrown into the Sea; if ſo, believe I've no deſires to be poſſeſt of what I moſt adore, fair Bebbemeah.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: (aſide) O that bewitching Tongue! 'twil quite undo all my firm Reſolutions. (To him) I told you I forgave you, is not that enough?

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: O no, you do not, if you did you'd run into theſe faithful loving Arms; convince me that you do ſo, and let me conduct you home.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: How Munzuffer! can you think I will return to live in the ſame place where my blaſted Fame by this is grown the publick Talk? No, I will ſeek ſome Deſart far from the Society of human Converſation, where I will ſpend my melancholy days, and ne'er return to this bad World again.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Is this Forgiveneſs, obdurate Bebbemeah? I cannot live without you, I ſwear by all that's good I will not, the minute that you leave me I'le with my Blood, ſince nothing elſe will do, implore your Pity, and waſh away my Guilt.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I could moſt willingly conſent to your Deſires, but ſtill ſo much I owe my injur'd Honour, I muſt and will reſolve to never ſee thee more; take, if you will, a parting Kiſs, ſure I may give that without offence to Modeſty, ſince 'tis the laſt Favour you muſt e'er receive from Bebbemeah's Love; for, O Munzuffer! canſt thou think it, for all this uſage I have had, I love thee ſtill?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: O no, I will not taſte of Bliſs, to make the deprivation of it more intolerable: Since then it muſt be ſo, farewel indeed for ever.

div.stage: (Offers to ſtab himſelf, but is prevented by Sennorat's entring.)

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Raſh Boy! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: O! I can hold no longer. Runs into his Arms. My moſt dear Lord, thou ſhalt not die, if the poſſeſſion of thy Bebbemeah can give you Life; I yield to thy all-conquering Love, diſpoſe me as you will, clear but my Reputation, and I'm yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Some help, good Sir, to ſupport this Extaſie, I've now more need of Moderation than under my preſſing Grief: Am I awake? I know not how to truſt my Senſes with this happy change of my Condition.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: I'm glad, fair injur'd Lady, there's no uſe for my Authority to carry you back: Your Reputation has, if poſſible, receiv'd a double Luſtre by the black detraction; all wait with eager haſte to ſee due Juſtice done on your inhuman Mother, and in a fury they drag the Body of wicked Cemat about the Streets; I've brought a Chariot to conduct you home in triumph o'er your Foes.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le wait upon you when you pleaſe; Sardea, ſtay and let our kind Landlord and his Family know where I wou'd ſee them, to gratifie their Troubles. Gives Munzuffer her Hand.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.l: Bear witneſs, Gods, I envy not your boaſted Bliſs above,
Nor would I change my Happineſs to be the mighty Jove.
sp.stage: Chavo looks after them, comes forward ſcratching his Head.
sp.p: Look ye there now, I thought how much you'd ſpeak a good word for one; I wou'd that old Man had e'en let him have kill'd himſelf, and then may be I might have got her in the mind, and now he's gone away with her, and I ſhall never zee her again all days of my breath. (almoſt crying) You might a been aſham'd to zay ſhe waz your Siſter, and make a body zet ones Heart upon her, zo you might then. cries.

sp.speaker: Sard.
sp.p: Alas poor Chavo! come man, have patience, you ſhall ſee her again preſently, did you not hear her invite you to her Houſe? come, come, there's Hopes ſtill, dry up your Eyes, we'l take your Father and Mother and follow her. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Callapia diſtracted, a Prieſt following her.

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: Will you not think on your unhappy ſtate? You cannot hope for Pardon in this World, you know your Crimes deſerve none, repent e're 'tis too late, or you will be condemn'd to the infernal Dungeon, where you muſt live in endleſs Torments, ne'r to be releas'd.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I'le tell you a Secret, but be ſure you tell no body of it: Ceres will ſend her winged Dragons for me, and bear me thro' the Air, I'le get into the Zodiac, turn the Bear out of her Skin, and creep into't, ſo cloſe that they ſhall never find me; ha, ha, ha, how I ſhall laugh to look down and ſee 'em ſearching for me!

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: Sure ſhe's diſtracted, I know not what to think of her. Madam, will you not think of your Condition?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Ha! thou art old Pechai, I know thee now; did I not poiſon thee? Away, away with that old worn-out Face, I'le ſend thee to Medea to be new boil'd, and when thou art young again I will be fond of thee; let her take pattern by Munzuffer, be ſure you be like him, I will not love thee elſe.

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: I find it now, her Guilt has turn'd her Brain, there is no hopes to make a Mad-woman hear Reaſon, ſhe may perhaps have an outragious Fit, and do me miſchief. offers to ſteal off, ſhe catches hold of him.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Wilt thou then leave me, cruel Munzuffer? I will not part with thee; thus, thus I'le claſp thee to me, holds him faſt in her arms. and keep thee from thy loved Bebbemeah. Ha, ſtand off, Throws him from her thou art not that ſweet lovely Youth; foh. foh, how thou ſtink'ſt of Lechery! Huſh, not a word, 'tis the Devil, I know him by his cloven Foot and that ſulphureous ſtink of Brimſtone: Softly, ſoftly, he'l hear thee elſe, he has damnable quick Ears. Hey ho, my Head akes for want of ſleep, let me have ſome Muſick: How goes the time, Father, will it ne'er be Night?

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: I hope her Fit is over, and ſhe will have an interval of Senſe; it grows late, Madam, the Officers by this time wait for you, repent and think whither you are going.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Did not I call for Muſick? but let it be ſuch as will beſt ſuit the Diſcord of my Soul, the Shrieks of the Damned, the Cries of tortur'd Infants, the Howlings of the Free born Wretch condemn'd to endleſs Slavery; this is the Harmony will pleaſe my Ear. Hark! did you not hear the clattering of Chains? Oh for Aeneas's Cloak to ſhroud me in: Who art thou? ſpeak: 'tis poor Choufera, I know her by her Wound. (takes hold of him) Truſt me, it makes me weep; poor Girl! I'le bath it with my Tears, and fetch thee back to life. Ha, ha, ha, I've thought of an excellent Expedient, I'le let out the old Prieſt's Blood, and fill her empty Veins, I warrant her after this tranſmutation, ſhe'l never die to ſave her Chaſtity again.

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: She is relaps'd, wou'd I were fairly rid of her. offers to go.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not go, we are to have a Feaſt, which you muſt partake of: Fie, fie, leave a Banquet, where thou maiſt feaſt thy moſt luxurious Gut with choiceſt Dainties! I'le ſnatch the curling Snakes from Tiryphone's Head, 'twill make a moſt delicious Diſh; a Sallad too we'l have of Aconite and Hellebore, and drink in flowing Bowls, inſtead of Nectar, Blood; what think'ſt thou of that? I know it will down with thee ſeaſon'd with a Gold Goblet: Prithee tell me, how do they fare in Hell?

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: Too ſoon I fear you'l know, moſt miſerable Woman.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Cannot you tell, d'ye ſay? be gone and ſee, ſtabs him. be ſure you bring me word. falls and dies.

sp.speaker: Prie.
sp.p: Oh! I am ſlain!—

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: I charge you clear the way, I do not love a Crowd, tell 'em I'm coming, bid old Charon be ready with his Boat. Ha! what's this, a Showre of Blood! 'tis old Pechai's, where, where ſhall I ſhelter, 'twil drown me, who'd a thought he had ſo much in his old ſhrivel'd Body? I'm ſick at Heart, oh for a Cordial from the Lethean River, to paſs a dark Oblivion on all my forepaſt Life. (Enter Sennorat, Munzuffer and Bebbemeah) Who are theſe, the infernal Judges?

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p:
Ha, what means this, a holy Father ſlain! had you not Murder enough upon your guilty Soul, but you muſt add a freſh one juſt as you're going to give an Account in the other World of what you've done already, impious Sinner! Call for the Officers, and let her preſently
be executed, each minute that ſhe lives draws a new Crime upon her. They all ſtand looking on the Body.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, (ſhe pulls Senn. away) 'tis Cerberus, don't wake him, he'l give a triple bark will fright us back to Hell again.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: What, you would feign Diſtraction to ſave your Life! that will not do, Lady, we too well know you Miſtreſs of the Trade of Falſhood and Deceit; I brought theſe wrong'd Lovers, that you may ask Forgiveneſs before you leave the World, for the unheard-of Injuries you have done them.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Lovers, ſay you! O they are Orpheus and Euridice; take, take her, and run away with her, don't you look back and loſe her again, you have ventur'd hard for her, but not ſo much as I have done for cruel unkind Munzuffer. Ha! do you not ſee you blazing Comet? it points juſt full at me: Shoot, ſhoot, I fear you not, you cannot pierce my Heart, 'tis hard as ſolid Adamantine Rocks, and will rebound your Darts up to the Skies again.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Do not thus madly rave, but tell me why you kill'd this holy Man; What cou'd provoke you to ſuch a curſed deed?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Look not on him, 'tis Meduſa's Head, 'twil turn thee into ſtone as hard as Munzuffer's ſtubborn Heart alwaies was to me.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: Alas, I pity her, ſhe's mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: Reſerve thy Pity for a nobler Cauſe, ſhe deſerves it not from any; Vexation and Deſpair has made her thus.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: If ſhe has loſt her Senſes, ſhe has not her wicked Inclinations, there's a freſh bleeding Inſtance of it. points to the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: I can't but have Compaſſion for the Mother of my dear Choufera.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: And for the Murdreſs of thy Father, Bebbemeah, think of that.

sp.speaker: Beb.
sp.p: That was indeed a helliſh fact, and ne'er to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Forgiveneſs ſay you! is there then Mercy for me? did you not talk of my Choufera? O ſhew me where ſhe is: I ſee her, ſhe's yonder fleeting in the milky way; ſtay, ſtay, dear Child, and take thy Mother with thee: wonderful! ſhe's diſſolv'd into a Star, and ſhines juſt in my Face, I cannot bear the Luſtre, my Eye-balls ake with gazing, let me repoſe them in eternal Night, and lay me faſt to ſleep, where I may never never wake again. ſhe lies down.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Yes, you ſhall be laid to ſleep, but will be quickly rous'd by Pains will keep you ever waking.

div.stage: Enter Officers, Muto, Metam, Chavo, and Sardea.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Alack poor Gentlewoman, ſhe's in a pitiful plight, ſhe's upon the hard floor, poor Soul.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Ai, ai, I warrant you'd have no Woman die for poiſoning her Husband, 'tis that you'd all be at if you dar'd; e'en let her be burnt, I ſay, ſhe deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Do your Office, and take her to the Stake, ſecure her faſt, ſhe either feigns a Lunacy, or is ſo; there lies a holy man juſt ſlain by her.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: (riſing a little) I've thought upon't, that is old Radamanthus, do but blot out the Murder of my Husband, and the falſe imputation laid on Bebbemeah, I'le ſtand my Tryal for the reſt. Ha! 'tis Cemat, now I will be reveng'd on him indeed, I'le ſpoil his Evidence in Hell againſt me: ſee, ſee, he ſteals away, will you not ſtop him? he's gone, and I will follow him, he ſhall not 'ſcape my Vengeance ſo. ſtabs her ſelf. Haſte, haſte Callapia, you'l quickly overtake him, 'tis a broad Road, and down Hill all the way. Dies.

sp.speaker: Senn.
sp.p: Unhappy Woman! thou haſt put a dreadful period to thy wickedneſs, and draws Compaſſion from me, tho' an Enemy to all thy Cruelties. Now, Bebbemeah, I'le reſign the Charge your noble Father truſted me withal, and thus I give it up. gives her to Munzuffer. Take her, Munzuffer, and beg the Gods to give thee Merit to deſerve the richeſt Prize that ever happy Youth was bleſt with.

sp.speaker: Munz.
sp.p: From the great Gods and you I thankfully receive the only Bleſſing which they have in ſtore to make Munzuffer happy. Riſſes her Hand.

lg.l: So the joy'd Merchant, who with Storms long toſt
Sees his dear Wealth and Hopes of Life all loſt:
When unexpected the Heavens grow clear and ſmile,
And ſafely lands him after all his Toil,
At the long-wiſh'd for Haven;
Such Joys too weakly does my Bliſs expreſs,
No Thoughts or Words can reach my Happineſs. Exeunt omnes.

sp.l: MY Faather is a Landed Man, haz Acres of hiz own,
Pays ſcot and lot, and Office bears, beholden is to none;
Haz Cow and Kine, haz Goats and Horſe, and Rupies too good ſtore,
Which will be Chavo's all in time, with many a good thing more,
Two Folds of Sheep, an Herd of Boars the common ſize exceeding;
And zince from Holland came their ſize, you need not doubt their breeding.
A flock of Geeſe of wiſeſt Race, came from Fingallian Highland,
Enough to plant a Colony in a Weſt Indian Iſland.
Of Aſſes too as grave as Sancho's he up to War does train,
To car the Engliſh powder'd Beaux to make the next Campaign.
And ſomething elſe ſhall nameleſs be, Chavo has more than Purſe;
If all will not your Favour win, adz fleſh, you may do worſe.
